# Intake Brief: 9-Card Golf (CG-0MLSDW7YM1IWH2SB)

**Priority: Critical** | **Type: Feature (Epic)** | **Assignee: Map**

> First engine spike: build a playable single-round 9-Card Golf game (human vs. AI) to validate the Tableau Card Engine architecture end-to-end and surface missing abstractions before tackling larger games.

## Problem Statement

The Tableau Card Engine has a working scaffold (toolchain, project structure, Phaser integration) but zero game logic, card abstractions, or gameplay features. A small, well-scoped spike is needed to validate the engine architecture end-to-end — from card data models through game rules to a playable Phaser UI — and to surface missing framework capabilities before tackling larger games. 9-Card Golf's tiny rule set (flip, swap, discard on a 3x3 grid) makes it the ideal first spike.

## Users

- **Engine developer (primary):** Validates that the engine's modular architecture (card-system, rule-engine, core-engine, ui) can support a real game. Uses the spike to discover which abstractions are missing and which APIs need refinement.
  - *"As an engine developer, I want to build a complete card game using the engine modules so I can identify gaps in Card, Deck, Pile, and Grid abstractions before building more complex games."*

- **QA / AI tester:** Uses an AI player to exercise all game paths (random + greedy strategies) and produce reproducible game transcripts for regression testing.
  - *"As a tester, I want an AI opponent that can play complete games automatically so I can validate scoring, turn flow, and edge cases without manual play."*

- **Game designer (future):** Uses the completed spike as a reference implementation and template for building additional example games.
  - *"As a game designer, I want a working reference game that demonstrates how to wire up scenes, rules, and UI so I can quickly scaffold new card games."*

## Success Criteria

1. **Playable single round:** A human player can play a complete single round of 9-Card Golf against 1 AI opponent in a Phaser scene — including initial card reveal, draw/swap/discard turns, and end-of-round scoring.
2. **AI player with two strategies:** An AI player is implemented with both random (valid moves) and greedy (minimize visible score) strategies, selectable at game start or via configuration.
3. **Correct scoring:** Scoring logic correctly implements: A=1, 2=-2, 3-10=face value, J/Q=10, K=0, three-of-a-kind columns=0. Automated unit tests cover at least 3 distinct scoring scenarios (including a column-of-three-of-a-kind case).
4. **Game transcript:** Each completed game produces a JSON transcript recording the full sequence of turns, actions, and resulting board states — sufficient to replay and verify the game.
5. **Visual replay (stretch goal):** A visual replay capability captures a screenshot or canvas snapshot per turn for human review of completed games. This is a stretch goal for this spike — a dedicated dev tool for game log playback and screenshot capture will be tracked separately.

## Constraints

- **First spike — no existing game logic:** All four engine modules (card-system, core-engine, rule-engine, ui) are currently empty stubs (version constants only). Every game-related abstraction must be built from scratch during this spike.
- **Card assets incomplete:** Only 2 placeholder SVGs exist (ace_of_spades.svg, card_back.svg at 140x190px). A full 52-card deck of face assets is needed. Assets must be CC0 or permissively licensed (MIT, Apache 2.0, or similar) per project policy.
- **No assumptions about framework features:** This is the project's first game spike. Do not assume any framework features exist beyond the proven scaffold (Vite, TypeScript, Phaser, Vitest). Missing capabilities must be built or sourced as part of the spike.
- **Single round only:** Scope is limited to one round of play (one deal through to scoring). Multi-round / "9 holes" format is out of scope.
- **1 Human + 1 AI:** Player count is fixed at one human and one AI opponent for this spike.
- **Licensing:** All assets and code must be open and freely available for commercial use per CREDITS.md policy.

## Existing State

- **Toolchain:** Fully operational — Vite 6.1, TypeScript 5.7 (strict mode), Vitest 3.0, Phaser 3.90.0. Dev server on port 3000, production builds to `dist/`.
- **Project structure:** Monorepo layout with `src/` (engine modules) and `example-games/` (game spikes). Path aliases configured (`@core-engine/*`, `@card-system/*`, `@rule-engine/*`, `@ui/*`).
- **Engine modules:** All four modules (`card-system`, `core-engine`, `rule-engine`, `ui`) exist as directories with barrel `index.ts` files exporting only version constants. Zero implementation.
- **Hello-world example:** Working Phaser scene proving SVG asset loading, tween animations, and text rendering. No interactivity or game logic. Establishes card dimensions (140x190px) and scene patterns.
- **Assets:** 2 SVGs (ace of spades face, card back) at 140x190px in `public/assets/cards/`. Attribution in `CREDITS.md`.
- **Tests:** Single smoke test confirming Vitest works. No meaningful game or engine tests.

## Desired Change

Build a playable 9-Card Golf example game at `example-games/golf/` that exercises and populates the engine modules:

- **card-system:** Implement Card type (rank, suit, faceUp), Deck (create, shuffle, draw), and Pile (push, pop, peek) abstractions. Add a Grid[3][3] type (may live locally in the golf game initially).
- **rule-engine:** Implement Golf-specific turn logic (draw from pile or discard, replace grid card or discard drawn card), end-of-round detection (all cards face-up), and scoring rules.
- **core-engine:** Implement minimal game state management and turn sequencing sufficient to drive a 2-player (human + AI) game loop.
- **ui:** Build Phaser scene(s) for the golf game: 3x3 grid layout, draw/discard piles, card flip/swap animations, score display, turn indicators.
- **AI player:** Implement two strategies (random valid move, greedy minimize-score) behind a selectable interface.
- **Recording:** Produce a JSON game transcript per completed game. Per-turn visual snapshots are a stretch goal (see Risks & Assumptions).
- **Card assets:** Source or generate a complete 52-card deck of face SVGs (CC0/permissive) at 140x190px. Update `public/assets/CREDITS.md` with attribution.
- **Tests:** Unit tests for scoring logic (minimum 3 scenarios), turn legality, and deck operations. All tests must pass via `npm test`; build must succeed via `npm run build`.

## Risks & Assumptions

### Risks
- **Scope creep from engine extraction:** Building reusable engine modules alongside a game spike may slow progress. Mitigation: build game-specific implementations first, then extract to shared modules only where the abstraction is clear and stable.
- **Card asset sourcing:** Finding or generating 52 CC0/permissive SVG card faces at consistent quality and dimensions (140x190px) may take non-trivial effort. Mitigation: consider programmatic SVG generation or an existing open-source deck (e.g., the SVG-cards GitHub repo).
- **Visual replay deferred:** Per-turn screenshot capture is a stretch goal for this spike. A dedicated dev tool for game log playback and image capture (using Playwright or similar) will be built as a separate high-priority work item, blocked by this spike. See related work item below.
- **Grid abstraction placement:** Unclear whether Grid[3][3] should live in card-system (reusable) or locally in the golf game. Mitigation: build locally first; extract after a second game validates the abstraction.

### Assumptions
- A standard 52-card deck (no jokers) is sufficient for 9-Card Golf.
- The 9-card variant uses the scoring rules from Wikipedia (A=1, 2=-2, 3-10=face, J/Q=10, K=0, column-of-three=0). No house-rule variants are in scope.
- Phaser 3.90.0's built-in scene management and tween system are sufficient for card flip/swap animations without additional libraries.
- The AI player does not need to be competitive — it only needs to make legal moves to exercise game paths.

## Suggested Next Step

Break CG-0MLSDW7YM1IWH2SB into child work items covering: card asset sourcing, card-system implementation, rule-engine (Golf scoring + turn logic), core-engine (game loop + state), UI (Phaser scenes), AI player, game recording, and test suite. Then begin implementation of the first child item per `wl next`.

## Related Work

- **Game Log Visual Replay Dev Tool (CG-0MLSN2YWY1EL17FN):** High-priority feature to build a Playwright-based dev tool that replays JSON game transcripts and captures per-turn screenshots. Blocked by this spike (requires working game with transcript output).
- **Scaffold Card Game Engine project (CG-0MLSFU7300TLFCBH):** Completed epic that set up the repository structure, toolchain, and empty module stubs. This spike builds directly on that foundation.
- **Wikipedia — Golf (card game):** https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Golf_(card_game) — Canonical rules reference.
- **BoardGameGeek — Golf:** https://boardgamegeek.com/wiki/page/Golf — Variant rules and community discussion.
- **AGENTS.md:** Project rules, spike-driven development approach, engine architecture, and quality gates.
- **docs/DEVELOPER.md:** Developer setup, build/test commands, and asset management.
- **public/assets/CREDITS.md:** Asset attribution policy and suggested sources (OpenGameArt.org, Kenney.nl, SVG-cards repo).

## Related work (automated report)

Searched Worklog (keywords: golf, card, game, spike, scoring, grid, deck, phaser) and repository files. No duplicate work items found.

### Worklog items

- **Scaffold Card Game Engine project (CG-0MLSFU7300TLFCBH)** [completed]: Established the repository structure, Vite/TypeScript/Phaser toolchain, hello-world example, and empty engine module stubs. This spike is a direct dependency — it provides the foundation (build tooling, directory layout, card asset pipeline patterns) that the Golf spike will build on. The hello-world scene patterns (SVG loading at 140x190px, Phaser.Scene subclass, game config) serve as templates for the Golf scene implementation.

- **Game Log Visual Replay Dev Tool (CG-0MLSN2YWY1EL17FN)** [blocked by this item]: High-priority feature to build a Playwright-based CLI tool that replays JSON game transcripts and captures per-turn screenshots. Directly blocked by this spike — it requires a working game producing JSON transcripts. The transcript format defined by this Golf spike will become the initial schema for the replay tool.

- **Beleaguered Castle (CG-0MLSDWFLT1WB6IEB)** [blocked by this item]: Open solitaire spike with deterministic, all-face-up gameplay. Blocked by this spike because it will reuse Card, Deck, and Pile abstractions built here. Its tableau/foundation model will exercise different engine patterns (build-up-by-suit vs. Golf's grid/scoring), providing a second validation point for engine module APIs.

- **Sushi Go! (CG-0MLSDWSCG154TUEL)**, **Splendor (CG-0MLSDX4B91DG6S1A)**, **Lost Cities (CG-0MLSDXELC06VESJL)**, **The Mind (CG-0MLSDXNMM1R2IMT9)**, **Coloretto (CG-0MLSDXY9F1FSGQ38)** [all blocked]: Five additional game spikes at idea stage. All will consume the card-system and core-engine modules first built by this Golf spike. Not directly related but will benefit from abstractions validated here.

# Intake Brief: Beleaguered Castle (CG-0MLSDWFLT1WB6IEB)

**Priority: Medium** | **Type: Epic** | **Assignee: Map**

> Second engine spike: build a playable Beleaguered Castle solitaire game to validate single-player support, drag-and-drop interaction, undo/redo, and auto-move mechanics in the Tableau Card Engine.

## Problem Statement

The Tableau Card Engine currently supports only multi-player games (the core-engine requires 2+ players) and uses click-only input. A single-player solitaire game is needed to validate and extend the engine for: single-player GameState, drag-and-drop card interaction, undo/redo state management, and auto-move heuristics. Beleaguered Castle's fully deterministic, open-information rules (all cards face-up) make it an ideal spike for these features without the complexity of hidden state.

## Users

- **Engine developer (primary):** Validates that the engine's modular architecture can support single-player games, drag-and-drop input, undo/redo, and auto-move. Uses the spike to extend core-engine for 1-player support and extract reusable patterns.
  - *"As an engine developer, I want to build a single-player solitaire game using the engine modules so I can identify gaps in single-player support, input handling, and state history management."*

- **Solitaire player:** Plays Beleaguered Castle with modern digital solitaire UX: drag cards or click-to-move, undo/redo mistakes, and watch cards auto-move to foundations when safe.
  - *"As a player, I want to play Beleaguered Castle with both drag-and-drop and click-to-move input, full undo/redo, and auto-move to foundations so the game feels polished and responsive."*

- **Game designer (future):** Uses the completed spike as a reference for building other solitaire-style games using the engine's new single-player, drag-and-drop, and undo/redo capabilities.
  - *"As a game designer, I want a working solitaire reference game that demonstrates drag-and-drop, undo/redo, and auto-move so I can quickly scaffold similar card games."*

## Success Criteria

1. **Playable classic Beleaguered Castle:** A player can play a complete game of Beleaguered Castle (classic deal: aces pre-placed on foundations, 48 cards dealt into 8 columns of 6) in a Phaser scene from deal to win or loss.
2. **Dual input methods:** Cards can be moved via both drag-and-drop (drag from tableau pile to foundation or another tableau pile) and click-to-select/click-to-place. Invalid moves snap the card back / are rejected.
3. **Full undo/redo:** A reusable undo/redo module in `src/core-engine/` supports unlimited undo/redo steps. The player can step backward and forward through their entire move history.
4. **Auto-move to foundations + auto-complete:** Cards are automatically moved to foundations when safe to play (no tableau pile needs the card as a build target). When the remaining game is trivially winnable, auto-complete plays all remaining moves to completion.
5. **Win and no-moves detection:** The game detects when the player wins (all cards on foundations) and when no legal moves remain (game over / stuck).
6. **New game / restart:** The player can start a new game (fresh shuffle) or restart the current deal at any time via a UI button.
7. **Single-player core-engine support:** `src/core-engine/` GameState is modified to allow 1 player, enabling all future solitaire games to use the shared engine.
8. **JSON game transcript:** Each completed game produces a JSON transcript compatible with the existing Visual Replay Dev Tool.
9. **Test coverage:** Unit tests cover: deal logic, move legality (valid and invalid moves), foundation build-up rules, win detection, no-moves detection, undo/redo operations, auto-move heuristics, and scoring (if applicable). All tests pass via `npm test`; build succeeds via `npm run build`.

## Constraints

- **Classic deal only:** This work item covers the classic Beleaguered Castle deal (aces pre-placed on foundations, 48 cards into 8 columns of 6). The Citadel variant (all 52 cards in tableau) is tracked separately as CG-0MLTDXG3H0WCXMUV.
- **Single-player only:** No AI opponent or solver. The player makes all decisions.
- **Card assets already available:** A full 52-card SVG deck at 140x190px exists in `public/assets/cards/` (CC0 licensed). No new art assets are needed.
- **Rule engine still a stub:** The rule engine (`src/rule-engine/`) remains an empty stub. Beleaguered Castle rules should be built locally in the game first; extraction to the rule engine is out of scope unless a clear reusable pattern emerges.
- **Licensing:** All code and assets must be open and freely available for commercial use per project policy.
- **Layout:** Foundations across the top, 8 tableau columns below (digital solitaire convention, not the traditional center-foundations layout).

## Existing State

- **Card system (src/card-system/):** Mature. Card, Deck, Pile types with full test coverage. Pile supports LIFO push/pop/peek operations suitable for foundations and tableau columns.
- **Core engine (src/core-engine/):** Functional. GameState<T> and TurnSequencer, but requires 2+ players. Must be modified for single-player support.
- **Rule engine (src/rule-engine/):** Empty stub (version constant only).
- **UI (src/ui/):** HelpPanel and HelpButton components available. No drag-and-drop, card sprite, or game-play UI components exist.
- **Golf example game (example-games/golf/):** Completed first spike. Establishes patterns for: scene structure, game logic separation (rules/scoring as pure functions), AI strategies, game transcripts, browser tests with Phaser, and help panel integration.
- **Card assets:** 52 SVG card faces + card back at 140x190px in `public/assets/cards/`. CC0 licensed from saulspatz/SVGCards.
- **No solitaire-specific code exists:** No foundation logic, tableau column logic, drag-and-drop, auto-move, or undo/redo anywhere in the codebase.

## Desired Change

Build a playable Beleaguered Castle example game at `example-games/beleaguered-castle/` that introduces single-player, drag-and-drop, undo/redo, and auto-move capabilities:

- **core-engine (single-player):** Modify `createGameState()` to accept 1 player. Ensure TurnSequencer works correctly for single-player (turn "advancement" is a no-op or simply increments the move counter).
- **core-engine (undo/redo):** Build a reusable `UndoRedoManager` module in `src/core-engine/` that maintains a history stack of game states and supports unlimited undo/redo.
- **Game logic (example-games/beleaguered-castle/):**
  - Deal module: shuffle deck, remove aces to foundations, deal 48 cards into 8 columns of 6 (all face-up).
  - Move rules: move top card of any tableau column to a foundation (if next in suit sequence) or to another tableau column (if one rank lower, regardless of suit). Empty columns accept any card.
  - Win detection: all 52 cards on foundations.
  - No-moves detection: no legal moves remain across all tableau columns.
  - Auto-move: automatically move cards to foundations when safe (no tableau column needs the card). Auto-complete when trivially solvable.
- **Phaser UI (example-games/beleaguered-castle/scenes/):**
  - Layout: 4 foundation piles across the top, 8 tableau columns below.
  - Dual input: drag-and-drop cards between piles, or click-to-select then click-to-place.
  - Visual feedback: highlight valid drop targets, snap-back for invalid moves, card flip animations for foundation placement.
  - Undo/redo buttons and keyboard shortcuts.
  - Win/loss overlays.
  - Help panel with game rules (using reusable HelpPanel component).
- **Game transcript:** Produce a JSON transcript per completed game, compatible with the Visual Replay Dev Tool.
- **Tests:** Unit tests for deal logic, move legality, foundation rules, win/no-moves detection, undo/redo, and auto-move. Browser tests for Phaser rendering and interaction. All tests pass via `npm test`; build succeeds via `npm run build`.

## Risks & Assumptions

### Risks
- **Drag-and-drop complexity:** Implementing reliable drag-and-drop with Phaser (setDraggable, drag zones, drop zones, snap-back) is significantly more complex than click input. May require substantial iteration on hit detection and visual feedback.
- **Undo/redo state size:** Storing full game state snapshots for unlimited undo/redo could consume significant memory for long games. Mitigation: use a command pattern (store moves, not states) or delta-based approach to minimize memory usage.
- **Auto-move correctness:** Determining whether a card is "safe" to auto-move to a foundation requires checking whether any tableau column still needs the card as a build target. The heuristic must be conservative to avoid auto-moving cards that the player might want to keep available for tableau building. Mitigation: start with a simple safe-move heuristic and iterate.
- **Auto-complete detection:** Determining when the game is "trivially winnable" is non-trivial (requires checking that all remaining tableau cards can be played to foundations in some order). Mitigation: use a simple heuristic (e.g., all tableau cards are in ascending order within their columns) rather than a full solver.
- **Core-engine single-player change scope:** Modifying GameState to allow 1 player may have ripple effects on TurnSequencer and any code that assumes 2+ players. Mitigation: make the change backward-compatible and verify all existing Golf tests still pass.
- **Low win rate:** Beleaguered Castle has a relatively low win rate (~30% of random deals are solvable). Players may encounter many unwinnable deals. Mitigation: the no-moves detection will inform the player when they are stuck, and new-game/restart options allow quick recovery.
- **Undo/redo interaction with auto-move:** Undoing a move that triggered one or more auto-moves must correctly undo the entire chain (auto-moves + player move). Failure to do so would leave the game in an inconsistent state. Mitigation: treat auto-move chains as part of the triggering move in the undo history.

### Assumptions
- A standard 52-card deck (no jokers) is used.
- Beleaguered Castle uses the classic rules from Wikipedia: aces pre-placed on foundations, build foundations up by suit (A to K), build tableau columns down regardless of suit, only top card of each column is available, empty columns accept any card.
- Phaser 3.90.0's built-in drag-and-drop support (setDraggable, drag events, drop zones) is sufficient without additional libraries.
- The undo/redo module does not need to support branching history (tree-based undo); a simple linear stack is sufficient.
- The game does not need a solver or hint system for this spike.
- The JSON transcript format can follow the same general structure as the Golf transcript, adapted for solitaire moves.

## Suggested Next Step

Break CG-0MLSDWFLT1WB6IEB into child work items covering: core-engine single-player support, undo/redo module, Beleaguered Castle game logic (deal, rules, win/loss detection), auto-move heuristics, Phaser UI (layout, drag-and-drop, click-to-move, visual feedback), game transcript recording, help panel integration, and test suite. Then begin implementation per `wl next`.

- **9-Card Golf (CG-0MLSDW7YM1IWH2SB)** [completed]: First game spike. Provides reference patterns for scene structure, game logic separation, AI strategies, game transcripts, and test structure. Beleaguered Castle follows the same architectural patterns.
- **Card System Engine Module (CG-0MLSPHOWY1HSCIDX)** [completed]: Card, Deck, Pile types that Beleaguered Castle will reuse directly.
- **Core Engine Turn Sequencer (CG-0MLSPHU1C02RAGE0)** [completed]: GameState and TurnSequencer that must be modified for single-player support.
- **Game Log Visual Replay Dev Tool (CG-0MLSN2YWY1EL17FN)** [completed]: JSON transcript replay tool. Beleaguered Castle should produce compatible transcripts.
- **Help Screen with Game Rules (CG-0MLT0PM000TQRIXT)** [completed]: Reusable HelpPanel and HelpButton components to integrate into Beleaguered Castle.
- **Citadel variant option (CG-0MLTDXG3H0WCXMUV)** [open]: Follow-on work item for adding the Citadel variant deal to Beleaguered Castle.
- **Wikipedia -- Beleaguered Castle:** https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beleaguered_Castle -- Canonical rules reference.
- **AGENTS.md:** Project rules, spike-driven development approach, engine architecture, and quality gates.
- **docs/DEVELOPER.md:** Developer setup, build/test commands, adding example games, and asset management.

# Scaffold Card Game Engine Project

> **Headline**: Set up the Card Game Spikes repository with Phaser 3.x, TypeScript, Vite, and Vitest as a flat monorepo, unblocking all 7 planned game spikes.

## Problem Statement

The Card Game Spikes project is a completely greenfield repository with no source code, build tooling, or directory structure. All 7 planned example game spikes (9-Card Golf, Beleaguered Castle, Sushi Go!, Splendor, Lost Cities, The Mind, Coloretto) are blocked until a working project foundation is in place. A properly scaffolded project with build, test, and dev-server tooling is required before any game development can begin.

## Users

- **Game developers (internal)**: Agents and contributors who will implement the example card games and extract reusable engine components.
  - *As a game developer, I want to run a single command to start a dev server with hot-reload so I can iterate quickly on game code.*
  - *As a game developer, I want TypeScript configured with strict mode so I catch type errors early.*
  - *As a game developer, I want a clear directory structure so I know where to put shared engine code vs. game-specific code.*
- **Engine consumers (future)**: Developers who will reuse extracted engine modules for their own card games.
  - *As an engine consumer, I want shared modules (core-engine, card-system, rule-engine) organized in a discoverable way so I can import only what I need.*

## Success Criteria

1. Running `npm install && npm run dev` starts a Vite dev server that renders a minimal Phaser 3.x "hello world" scene in the browser (a card sprite or text on a colored background).
2. Running `npm test` executes Vitest and at least one passing unit test completes successfully.
3. Running `npm run build` produces a production bundle in a `dist/` directory without errors.
4. The directory structure includes clearly separated areas for shared engine modules (`src/core-engine/`, `src/card-system/`, `src/rule-engine/`, `src/ui/`) and example games (`example-games/`), with each example game having its own entry point and scene(s).
5. A git repository is initialized with a proper `.gitignore` (covering `node_modules/`, `dist/`, IDE files, OS files) and an initial commit containing the full scaffold.

## Constraints

- **Phaser 3.x (latest stable, currently 3.90.0)**: The AGENTS.md originally specified "Phaser 4" but this does not exist as a stable release. Phaser 3.x is the current community standard.
- **Vite**: Replaces Webpack as specified in AGENTS.md. Vite is officially supported by Phaser's project scaffolder and offers faster dev builds and HMR.
- **Vitest**: Replaces Jest as specified in AGENTS.md. Vitest integrates natively with Vite, uses the same API as Jest, and avoids ESM/CJS compatibility friction.
- **TypeScript**: Strict mode, targeting modern browsers (ES2020+).
- **Flat monorepo**: Single `package.json` at root. Shared engine code in `src/` subdirectories, example games in `example-games/` with their own scenes and entry points. No npm workspaces for now.
- **Open-source licensing**: All dependencies and assets must be permissively licensed (MIT, Apache 2.0, CC0, etc.) and suitable for commercial use.
- **AGENTS.md must be updated** to reflect the actual tech stack decisions (Phaser 3.x, Vite, Vitest, flat monorepo structure).

## Existing State

- The repository contains only `AGENTS.md`, `.gitignore` (minimal, Worklog-focused), and `.worklog/` data.
- No git repository is initialized (no `.git/` directory).
- No `package.json`, no TypeScript config, no build tooling, no source files, no tests.
- 7 game spike work items exist in Worklog, all at "idea" stage, all blocked pending scaffolding.

## Desired Change

After this work item is completed, the repository will contain:

- **Git repository**: Initialized with a proper `.gitignore` and initial commit.
- **`package.json`**: With Phaser 3.x, TypeScript, Vite, and Vitest as dependencies; scripts for `dev`, `build`, `test`, and `preview`.
- **`tsconfig.json`**: Strict TypeScript configuration targeting ES2020, with Phaser type definitions.
- **`vite.config.ts`**: Configured for Phaser 3.x development with dev server and production build.
- **Directory structure**:
  ```
  cardGameSpikes/
  ├── src/
  │   ├── core-engine/       # Game loop, state management, rendering helpers
  │   ├── card-system/       # Card definitions, deck, hand, pile abstractions
  │   ├── rule-engine/       # Rule definitions, validation, turn logic
  │   └── ui/                # Reusable UI components (buttons, menus, overlays)
  ├── example-games/
  │   └── hello-world/       # Minimal Phaser scene proving toolchain works
  │       ├── scenes/
  │       └── main.ts
  ├── public/                # Static assets (HTML, images, fonts)
  ├── tests/                 # Vitest test files
  ├── dist/                  # Production build output (gitignored)
  ├── AGENTS.md              # Updated with actual tech stack
  ├── package.json
  ├── tsconfig.json
  ├── vite.config.ts
  └── .gitignore             # Comprehensive Node.js/TS/Vite ignores
  ```
- **Hello-world scene**: A minimal Phaser 3.x scene that renders on screen, proving Vite + Phaser + TypeScript integration works end-to-end.
- **One passing Vitest test**: Demonstrating the test framework is wired up correctly.
- **Updated AGENTS.md**: Reflecting Phaser 3.x, Vite, Vitest, and the actual directory structure.

## Related Work

- **9-Card Golf (CG-0MLSDW7YM1IWH2SB)** - First game spike, directly unblocked by this scaffolding.
- **Beleaguered Castle (CG-0MLSDWFLT1WB6IEB)** - Solitaire spike, blocked.
- **Sushi Go! (CG-0MLSDWSCG154TUEL)** - Drafting game spike, blocked.
- **Splendor (CG-0MLSDX4B91DG6S1A)** - Engine-building game spike, blocked.
- **Lost Cities (CG-0MLSDXELC06VESJL)** - 2-player lanes spike, blocked.
- **The Mind (CG-0MLSDXNMM1R2IMT9)** - Open-hand variant spike, blocked.
- **Coloretto (CG-0MLSDXY9F1FSGQ38)** - Set-building tableau spike, blocked.
- **Official Phaser Webpack-TS template** (https://github.com/phaserjs/template-webpack-ts) - Reference for Phaser + TypeScript project structure.
- **Phaser `create-phaser-game` CLI** - Official scaffolder supporting Vite + TypeScript templates.

## Risks & Assumptions

- **Risk**: Phaser 3.x may not work seamlessly with Vite out of the box (e.g., global `Phaser` variable, canvas/WebGL initialization). *Mitigation*: The official `create-phaser-game` CLI has a Vite template, so this path is well-trodden.
- **Risk**: The flat monorepo approach may not scale if engine modules need independent versioning later. *Mitigation*: Acceptable for a spike-driven project; migration to workspaces can be done later without major refactoring.
- **Assumption**: Phaser 3.x TypeScript definitions are up-to-date and compatible with strict mode (they are shipped in the `phaser` npm package under `types/`).
- **Assumption**: A single Vite entry point can serve multiple example games. If not, a per-game Vite config or multi-page setup may be needed (discoverable during first game spike implementation).
- **Assumption**: No CI/CD pipeline is needed in this scaffolding phase; local `npm test` and `npm run build` are sufficient validation.

## Suggested Next Step

Break this epic into child work items for implementation: (1) git init + .gitignore, (2) package.json + Vite + TypeScript config, (3) directory structure + placeholder modules, (4) hello-world Phaser scene, (5) Vitest setup + first test, (6) AGENTS.md update. Then implement starting from work item CG-0MLSFU7300TLFCBH.

- **AGENTS.md** (`/AGENTS.md`): The project charter defining the vision, directory structure, and tech stack for the Card Game Engine. This scaffolding work item directly implements the foundational setup described in AGENTS.md, with agreed deviations (Phaser 3.x instead of 4, Vite instead of Webpack, Vitest instead of Jest).
- **9-Card Golf (CG-0MLSDW7YM1IWH2SB)**: The first and highest-priority game spike. It is directly unblocked by this scaffolding and will be the first consumer of the project structure, Phaser integration, and test framework established here. Its description references `Phaser Container` which validates the need for a working Phaser setup.
- **Beleaguered Castle (CG-0MLSDWFLT1WB6IEB)**, **Sushi Go! (CG-0MLSDWSCG154TUEL)**, **Splendor (CG-0MLSDX4B91DG6S1A)**, **Lost Cities (CG-0MLSDXELC06VESJL)**, **The Mind (CG-0MLSDXNMM1R2IMT9)**, **Coloretto (CG-0MLSDXY9F1FSGQ38)**: All 6 remaining game spikes are blocked pending scaffolding. Each references card abstractions (Card, Deck, Pile, Hand, etc.) that will live in the `src/card-system/` module created by this work.
- **Official Phaser Webpack-TS template** (https://github.com/phaserjs/template-webpack-ts): The community reference implementation for Phaser + TypeScript project structure. While this project uses Vite instead of Webpack, the template's `src/` layout (scenes, game config, main entry point) is a useful structural reference.
- **Phaser `create-phaser-game` CLI**: The official Phaser scaffolder supports Vite + TypeScript templates and should be consulted during implementation for best-practice Vite configuration patterns.

  - *"As an engine developer, I want to replay a recorded game transcript and see per-turn screenshots so I can verify rendering correctness and visually debug game state issues."*

- **QA / tester:** Needs to generate reproducible visual evidence of bugs and regressions by replaying specific game transcripts that trigger known issues.
  - *"As a QA tester, I want to replay a game transcript that reproduces a bug, pause at the problematic turn, and take over interactively to investigate the issue in a live browser."*

- **Game designer:** Needs to review complete game playthroughs visually without playing them, for tuning game feel, animations, and UI layout.
  - *"As a game designer, I want to watch a recorded game play back visually so I can evaluate the game's visual presentation and identify UI improvements."*

## Success Criteria

1. **Screenshot capture:** Running `npm run replay -- data/transcripts/golf/game-001.json --output data/screenshots/golf/game-001/` replays the transcript in a headless Playwright browser and produces a PNG screenshot after each turn, saved to the specified output directory.
2. **Transcript auto-save:** Games automatically save completed transcripts to browser storage (IndexedDB preferred, localStorage fallback) with a rolling window of the last 10 games. A CLI script (`npm run transcripts:export -- golf`) extracts transcripts from browser storage to `data/transcripts/golf/` on disk. An in-game export button also allows manual JSON download.
3. **Partial replay with takeover:** The replay tool supports `--stop-at <turn>` (e.g., `npm run replay -- transcript.json --stop-at 12`) which pauses replay at the specified turn and keeps the browser open in non-headless mode, allowing the developer to take manual control and play from that point.
4. **Engine event system:** The core engine module (`src/core-engine/`) emits standardized events (`turn-started`, `turn-completed`, `animation-complete`, `state-settled`, `game-ended`) that the replay tool listens for to ensure precise timing between turns.
5. **Golf game support:** The tool works with the existing 9-Card Golf transcript format (version 1) as the initial supported game, with architecture designed to support additional games without major refactoring.
6. **Documentation:** `docs/DEVELOPER.md` is updated with usage instructions for the replay tool, transcript auto-save/export, and the engine event system.

## Constraints

- **Canvas-based rendering:** Phaser renders to a WebGL/Canvas element, not DOM. Playwright cannot use CSS selectors for game elements. The tool must use coordinate-based clicking or the game must expose hit area information for reliable interaction.
- **Browser storage for persistence:** Transcripts are saved to localStorage/IndexedDB since the game runs in a browser and the Vite dev server does not natively support disk writes. A separate CLI step is needed to extract transcripts to disk files.
- **Playwright dependency:** Playwright is already a devDependency (^1.58.2) used for Vitest browser tests. The replay tool must not conflict with the existing test configuration.
- **Existing transcript schema:** The tool must consume the existing `GameTranscript` format (version 1) defined in `example-games/golf/GameTranscript.ts`. Changes to the schema should be backward-compatible.
- **Video capture is a stretch goal:** Per-turn PNG screenshots are the primary output. Stitching screenshots into a video or recording continuous video is deferred to a follow-up enhancement.
- **Licensing:** All new dependencies must be permissively licensed (MIT, Apache 2.0, CC0, or similar).

## Existing State

- **Transcript system:** A well-tested `TranscriptRecorder` class exists in `example-games/golf/GameTranscript.ts` that captures complete board state per turn (player grids, discard pile, stock count, scores). The transcript is currently held in-memory only and used for the end-of-game results screen.
- **Transcript format:** Version 1 schema is defined as TypeScript interfaces (`GameTranscript`, `TurnRecord`, `BoardSnapshot`, `CardSnapshot`, `GameResults`). Comprehensive unit and integration tests validate transcript correctness and JSON round-trip serialization.
- **Playwright integration:** Already installed as a devDependency and configured as the Vitest browser test provider (headless Chromium). Browser tests exist for Golf UI interactions (`tests/golf/GolfInteraction.browser.test.ts`).
- **No replay tool:** No replay, playback, or screenshot capture functionality exists. No dev tools infrastructure exists. No `tools/` directory.
- **No transcript persistence:** Transcripts are not saved to disk or browser storage. They exist only in-memory during a game session.
- **No engine event system:** The core engine does not emit events for turn lifecycle or animation timing. The Golf scene manages its own animation callbacks internally.

## Desired Change

Build a developer replay tool with these capabilities:

### Transcript Persistence (child task)
- Implement auto-save of completed game transcripts to browser storage (localStorage or IndexedDB) after each game.
- Maintain a rolling window of the last 10 transcripts per game.
- Add an in-game export button that downloads the current transcript as a JSON file.
- Create a CLI extraction script (`npm run transcripts:export`) that uses Playwright to connect to the game, read transcripts from browser storage, and write them as JSON files to `data/transcripts/<game>/`.
- Add `data/` to `.gitignore`.

### Core Engine Event System (child task)
- Add a standardized event emitter to the core engine module (`src/core-engine/`) that games can use to signal turn lifecycle events.
- Define events: `turn-started`, `turn-completed`, `animation-complete`, `state-settled`, `game-ended`.
- Integrate the event system into the Golf scene so it emits these events at appropriate points.
- Design for reuse across all example games.

### Replay Tool (primary deliverable)
- Create an npm script entry point (`npm run replay`) that accepts a transcript JSON file path and replays it.
- Use Playwright to launch the game in a headless browser, then drive it through recorded turns using coordinate-based UI automation.
- Use core engine events to synchronize between turns (wait for `state-settled` before capturing screenshots and advancing).
- Capture a PNG screenshot of the Phaser canvas after each turn, saved to a configurable output directory (default: `data/screenshots/<game>/<timestamp>/`).
- Support `--stop-at <turn>` to pause at a specific turn, switch to non-headless mode, and hand the browser off to the developer for interactive takeover.
- Produce a summary report (JSON) listing turns replayed, screenshot paths, and any errors encountered.
- Design the tool architecture to be game-agnostic where possible, with game-specific adapters for translating transcript moves into UI interactions.

### Documentation
- Update `docs/DEVELOPER.md` with usage instructions for the replay tool, transcript export, and the engine event system.

## Risks & Assumptions

### Risks
- **Canvas interaction reliability:** Coordinate-based clicking on Phaser canvas elements may be fragile if game layout changes or window size varies. Mitigation: use the engine event system and game-exposed hit area data to improve targeting; pin viewport dimensions during replay.
- **Animation timing:** Replaying turns faster than animations complete could cause visual artifacts or incorrect screenshots. Mitigation: the engine event system (`state-settled` event) ensures the tool waits for animations to finish before capturing.
- **Browser storage limits:** localStorage has a ~5-10MB limit; 10 transcripts of complex games could approach this. Mitigation: use IndexedDB (larger quota) or compress transcripts before storage.
- **Scope creep:** This work item touches multiple systems (persistence, events, UI automation, CLI tooling). Mitigation: break into child tasks, implement incrementally, and record additional feature ideas (video capture, multi-game support) as separate work items rather than expanding scope.
- **Cross-game generalization:** Designing the event system and replay architecture for reuse before a second game validates it may lead to premature abstraction. Mitigation: implement for Golf first, keep interfaces minimal, refactor when Beleaguered Castle or another game adds replay support.
- **Dev server dependency:** The replay tool assumes a running Vite dev server at `localhost:3000`. If the server is not running, replay will fail silently or with an unclear error. Mitigation: the replay script should check for a running server before launching Playwright and provide a clear error message with instructions to start the dev server.
- **Transcript schema drift:** If the transcript format evolves (e.g., for Beleaguered Castle), older transcripts may become incompatible. Mitigation: the transcript schema includes a `version` field; the replay tool should validate the version and fail gracefully with a clear message if the format is unsupported.

### Assumptions
- Playwright's canvas screenshot API produces sufficiently high-quality captures of the Phaser rendering for visual verification.
- The existing Golf scene's UI layout is stable enough for coordinate-based interaction (card positions, pile locations are deterministic for a given viewport size).
- The `state-settled` event pattern is sufficient for synchronizing between turns without needing frame-level precision.
- IndexedDB or localStorage provides adequate storage for 10 rolling transcripts without performance issues.
- The Vite dev server will be running when the replay tool is invoked (the tool connects to `localhost:3000`).

- **Golf browser tests** (`tests/golf/GolfInteraction.browser.test.ts`): Existing Playwright-based UI tests for the Golf scene. Demonstrates patterns for Phaser canvas interaction via Playwright that the replay tool can build on.

## Suggested Next Step

Break CG-0MLSN2YWY1EL17FN into child work items covering: transcript persistence (auto-save + export), core engine event system, replay tool implementation, and documentation. Then begin implementation per `wl next`.

As an engine developer, I want automated browser tests that verify the Phaser game renders correctly and responds to user interactions, so that UI regressions are caught before they reach players.

# Intake Brief: Help Screen with Game Rules and Instructions (CG-0MLT0PM000TQRIXT)

**Priority: Medium** | **Type: Feature** | **Assignee: Map**

> Add a reusable left-side help panel to the engine's UI module (`src/ui/`) that accepts an array of `{ heading, body }` content sections from each game, and integrate it into the 9-Card Golf example with rules overview, turn flow, scoring, and how-to-play instructions.

## Problem Statement

Players of Tableau Card Engine games currently have no way to learn the rules or how to play within the game itself. Rules exist only as code comments and developer documentation. A reusable, engine-level help panel is needed so that each game can surface its own rules and instructions to players without building custom UI from scratch.

## Users

- **Player (primary):** Wants to quickly reference the rules and how-to-play instructions without leaving the game.
  - *"As a player, I want to press a help button or keyboard shortcut to see the game's rules and instructions in a side panel so I can learn how to play or refresh my memory mid-game."*

- **Game developer (secondary):** Wants a ready-made, configurable help panel component they can populate with game-specific content.
  - *"As a game developer, I want to pass an array of content sections (heading + body) to a reusable help panel component so that I don't have to build help screen UI from scratch for each new game."*

## Success Criteria

1. **Reusable engine component:** A `HelpPanel` (or equivalent) class exists in `src/ui/` that accepts an array of `{ heading: string, body: string }` sections and renders them in a left-side slide-in panel.
2. **Trigger mechanisms:** The help panel can be opened via an on-screen help button (e.g. "?" icon) and a keyboard shortcut (e.g. H or ?), and dismissed via a close button, the same keyboard shortcut, or clicking outside the panel.
3. **Scrollable content:** If the rules content exceeds the panel height, the panel supports vertical scrolling with a visible scroll indicator.
4. **Percentage-based width:** The panel width is responsive, taking a percentage of the game canvas (e.g. 30-40%) rather than a fixed pixel width.
5. **Golf integration:** The 9-Card Golf example game integrates the help panel with sections covering rules overview, turn flow, scoring, and basic how-to-play instructions. The help panel is accessible during gameplay without pausing the game.

## Constraints

- **No game pausing:** The game continues running while the help panel is open. Game input behind the panel may be blocked (to prevent accidental clicks) but AI turns and animations are not frozen.
- **Engine-level component:** The `HelpPanel` must live in `src/ui/` and be importable via the `@ui/*` path alias. Game-specific content must not be hard-coded in the engine component.
- **Golf only (initial scope):** Only the 9-Card Golf game needs to integrate the help panel in this work item. Other games will adopt it later.
- **Content is not interactive:** The help panel displays static text sections. Interactive tutorials, animated demos, or step-by-step walkthroughs are out of scope.
- **Phaser 3.90.0 compatibility:** The component must work with the current Phaser version and use Phaser's built-in text rendering and input systems (no DOM overlays or external UI libraries).
- **Quality gates:** `npm test` and `npm run build` must pass after implementation.

## Existing State

- **`src/ui/` module:** Empty stub exporting only `UI_VERSION = '0.1.0'`. No reusable UI components exist.
- **End-screen overlay in GolfScene (lines 618-674):** The only overlay-like pattern in the codebase -- a semi-transparent rectangle with text and an interactive button. Hard-coded in the scene, not extracted. This serves as a reference for how overlays can be built in Phaser.
- **Instruction text in GolfScene:** A single-line contextual instruction text at the bottom of the screen that changes per turn phase. Not a help screen.
- **Rules in code only:** `GolfRules.ts` and `GolfScoring.ts` contain complete rules as JSDoc comments and imperative code, but no player-facing text or data structure exists for rules content.
- **No keyboard shortcut handling:** The Golf game uses only mouse/pointer input. No keyboard shortcuts are implemented.

## Desired Change

- **New engine component (`src/ui/HelpPanel.ts` or similar):**
  - Accepts a configuration object with an array of `{ heading: string, body: string }` content sections.
  - Renders a left-side panel that slides in/out with an animation.
  - Panel width is percentage-based (e.g. 30-40% of canvas width).
  - Includes a close button (e.g. "X" in the top-right corner of the panel).
  - Supports vertical scrolling with a scroll indicator when content overflows.
  - Provides a semi-transparent backdrop behind the panel (optional, to dim the game).

- **Help button (`src/ui/HelpButton.ts` or similar):**
  - A small on-screen button (e.g. "?" icon) that can be placed in a game scene to toggle the help panel.
  - Reusable across games.

- **Keyboard shortcut support:**
  - The help panel listens for a configurable keyboard shortcut (default: H or ?) to toggle open/close.
  - Clicking outside the panel also dismisses it.

- **Golf game integration (`example-games/golf/`):**
  - Define rules content as an array of sections (e.g. Overview, Turn Flow, Scoring, Tips).
  - Add the help button to the GolfScene.
  - Wire up the keyboard shortcut.

- **Tests:**
  - Unit tests for the HelpPanel component (content rendering, open/close state).
  - Integration verification that the Golf game's help content loads correctly.

- **Barrel exports:** Update `src/ui/index.ts` to export `HelpPanel`, `HelpButton`, and related types.

## Risks & Assumptions

### Risks
- **Phaser text scrolling limitations:** Phaser 3 does not have a native scrollable text container. Implementing smooth scrolling with a scroll indicator may require a masked container with drag/wheel input, adding complexity. Mitigation: research Phaser community patterns for scrollable panels before implementation; consider a crop-mask approach with pointer-drag and mouse-wheel listeners.
- **Input blocking complexity:** Blocking game input behind the panel while keeping the game running (AI turns, animations) may require careful Phaser input priority management. Mitigation: use Phaser's input hit area and depth sorting; test with active AI turns.
- **First `src/ui/` component sets precedent:** This is the first real component in the engine's UI module. Design decisions (API patterns, naming conventions, configuration approach) will influence all future UI components. Mitigation: keep the API surface minimal and well-documented; review before merging.
- **Content authoring effort underestimated:** Writing clear, concise player-facing rules text for Golf is a distinct task from building the UI component. Poor rules text undermines the feature even if the component works perfectly. Mitigation: draft rules content early and review for clarity before final integration.

### Assumptions
- Phaser 3.90.0's mask and input systems are sufficient for implementing a scrollable side panel without external libraries.
- A single keyboard shortcut (H key) is sufficient; no conflict with existing game input is expected since Golf currently uses only pointer input.
- Game-specific content will be plain text only (no rich formatting, images, or HTML). Markdown or styled text can be considered in future iterations.
- The panel does not need to persist state (e.g. scroll position) across open/close cycles.

## Related Work

- **9-Card Golf (CG-0MLSDW7YM1IWH2SB)** [completed]: The parent spike. The Golf game is the first integration target for this help screen feature.
- **Golf Phaser UI (CG-0MLSPJ9EW1WGHKLX)** [completed]: Established the Phaser scene patterns (overlays, text rendering, input handling) used in GolfScene. The help panel should follow similar patterns.
- **Beleaguered Castle (CG-0MLSDWFLT1WB6IEB)** [open]: Future game spike that will benefit from the reusable help panel.
- **Future game spikes** (Sushi Go!, Splendor, Lost Cities, The Mind, Coloretto): All will consume the help panel component once built.
- **`src/ui/index.ts`**: Stub module that will be populated by this work item.
- **`example-games/golf/scenes/GolfScene.ts`**: Scene that will integrate the help panel.
- **`example-games/golf/GolfRules.ts`**, **`GolfScoring.ts`**: Source material for the Golf game's help content sections.

## Related work (automated report)

Searched Worklog (keywords: help, panel, UI, overlay, scroll, button, keyboard, rules, instructions, Golf) and repository files. Conservative filtering applied -- only items with clear relevance to the help panel feature are included.

### Worklog items

- **Golf Phaser UI (CG-0MLSPJ9EW1WGHKLX)** [completed]: The most directly relevant prior work. GolfScene.ts (lines 618-674) contains the only overlay pattern in the codebase -- a semi-transparent rectangle with text and an interactive button for the end-of-round screen. This serves as the primary reference implementation for how to build overlay/panel UI in Phaser within this project, including depth management, text rendering, and interactive button patterns.

- **Golf Game Rules and Scoring (CG-0MLSPI9YQ083H8LO)** [completed]: Implemented the game rules (GolfRules.ts) and scoring logic (GolfScoring.ts) that contain the authoritative rule definitions as JSDoc comments and code. These files are the source material from which player-facing help content sections (rules overview, turn flow, scoring) must be derived. No player-facing text data structure exists yet -- this work item must create one.

- **Investigate and fix broken Golf UI interactions (CG-0MLSW8TKZ0YHXJR2)** [completed]: Fixed interaction handling in GolfScene (click handling, turn flow, AI execution, state transitions). Understanding these fixes is relevant because the help panel must coexist with the game's input handling -- blocking game clicks behind the panel while keeping AI turns and animations running requires awareness of the current input architecture.

- **Phaser UI Browser Testing with Vitest (CG-0MLSUJIE30K54IUO)** [completed]: Established browser-mode testing infrastructure using Vitest + Playwright. The help panel's unit and integration tests should follow the same patterns (*.browser.test.ts convention, window.__PHASER_GAME__ access for state assertions) to verify rendering and interaction in a real browser.

- **Beleaguered Castle (CG-0MLSDWFLT1WB6IEB)** [open, idea stage]: The next planned game spike. Will be the second consumer of the reusable HelpPanel component, validating that the API is truly game-agnostic. The help panel's content section interface ({ heading, body }) should be validated against this game's anticipated content needs.

- **Scaffold Card Game Engine project (CG-0MLSFU7300TLFCBH)** [completed]: Established the src/ui/ module stub and the @ui/* path alias. The HelpPanel and HelpButton components must be exported from src/ui/index.ts and importable via @ui/* per the project conventions set by this work item.

### Repository files

- **`src/ui/index.ts`**: Currently an empty stub exporting only `UI_VERSION = '0.1.0'`. This is where HelpPanel, HelpButton, and related types must be exported. As the first real component added to this module, the API design here sets a precedent for all future UI components.

- **`example-games/golf/scenes/GolfScene.ts`** (676 lines): The integration target scene. The end-screen overlay (lines 618-674) demonstrates the overlay pattern (semi-transparent background rectangle, centered text, interactive button with hover states, depth management). The help panel implementation should follow this pattern but extract it into a reusable, configurable component rather than hard-coding it in the scene.

- **`example-games/golf/GolfRules.ts`**: Contains complete turn flow rules as JSDoc (draw from stock/discard, swap or discard+flip, round ending detection, initial reveal). The help content's "Turn Flow" and "How to Play" sections should be derived from these documented rules.

- **`example-games/golf/GolfScoring.ts`**: Contains scoring rules as JSDoc (A=1, 2=-2, 3-10=face, J/Q=10, K=0, column-of-three=0). The help content's "Scoring" section should be derived from this documented logic.

- **`example-games/golf/GolfGrid.ts`**: Defines the 3x3 grid model (GRID_ROWS=3, GRID_COLS=3) used by the game. Relevant context for writing the help content's rules overview section explaining the grid layout.

## Summary

Add polished slide-in/slide-out animation with easing to the HelpPanel open/close transitions. The panel slides from off-screen left to its final position on open, and back off-screen on close, using Phaser tweens with cubic easing curves.

## User Story

As a player, I want the help panel to slide in and out smoothly so the UI feels polished and responsive rather than jarring.

## Acceptance Criteria

- Calling `open()` slides the panel from off-screen left to its final position using a Phaser tween with ease-out curve
- Calling `close()` slides the panel back off-screen left with ease-in curve
- Animation duration is configurable (default ~300ms)
- Calling `open()` while already open or `close()` while already closed is a no-op
- Calling `open()` while a close animation is in progress interrupts the close and animates to the open position without a visible position jump
- Pointer events on panel content (close button, scroll) do not fire during animation transitions
- Unit/browser test verifies animation completes and panel reaches final position

## Minimal Implementation

- Use `scene.tweens.add()` with `Phaser.Math.Easing.Cubic.Out` for open, `Cubic.In` for close
- Start panel at `x = -panelWidth`, animate to `x = 0` on open
- Track animation state to handle interruption (stop existing tween, start new one from current position)
- Disable panel interactivity during animation via a state flag

## Prototype / Experiment

Verify tween interruption (calling open during close) produces smooth reversal without visual glitches. Success = no position jump or orphaned tweens.

## Dependencies

- HelpPanel Core Component (CG-0MLTANMZ80E1GY0X)

## Deliverables

- Updated `src/ui/HelpPanel.ts` with animation logic
- Animation unit/browser tests

## Summary

When content sections exceed the panel's visible height, enable vertical scrolling via mouse wheel and pointer drag, with a minimal scroll track bar indicator. Content is clipped to panel boundaries using a Phaser mask.

## User Story

As a player, I want to scroll through long help content within the panel using my mouse wheel or by dragging, so I can read all the rules even if they don't fit on one screen.

## Acceptance Criteria

- If total content height exceeds panel height, scrolling is enabled automatically
- Mouse wheel scrolls content up/down within the panel bounds
- Pointer drag (click-and-drag) on the panel area scrolls content up/down
- Content is clipped to the panel boundaries using a Phaser mask (no text visible outside the panel)
- A thin vertical track bar on the right side of the panel shows relative scroll position
- Track bar updates position as the user scrolls
- If content fits within the panel, no track bar is shown and scrolling is disabled
- Scroll position resets to top each time the panel is opened
- Scrolling beyond the top boundary does not move content past the initial position (no over-scroll at top)
- Scrolling beyond the bottom boundary does not move content past the last section (no over-scroll at bottom)
- Unit/browser tests verify scroll behavior, clamping, and track bar visibility

- Wrap content text objects in a Phaser Container, apply a `GeometryMask` clipped to panel bounds
- Listen for `wheel` events on the scene/panel and adjust container Y offset within bounds
- Add pointer-drag input on the panel for touch/mouse drag scrolling
- Draw track bar as a thin Phaser Graphics rectangle; update its Y position proportional to scroll offset
- Calculate max scroll range from `totalContentHeight - visibleHeight`
- On `open()`, reset content container Y to 0 (top)

Verify Phaser 3.90.0 `GeometryMask` works correctly for clipping a scrollable container. Success = content clips cleanly at panel top/bottom boundaries with no visual artifacts.

## Summary

When the help panel slides open, the content area is blank. Text only appears after the user scrolls. This is because the GeometryMask is drawn at the container's x position at the time of opening (which is off-screen at -panelWidth), and is never updated during the slide-in animation.

## Root Cause

In resetScroll() (called by open()), the mask is drawn at maskX = this.container.x, which is -panelWidth (off-screen). The slide-in tween animates container.x from -panelWidth to 0, but the mask rectangle is not redrawn during the animation. The mask only gets redrawn when the user scrolls (applyScroll()), which is why content appears after scrolling.

## Fix

## Summary

Automatically move cards to foundations when safe to play after each player move, with compound undo support so undoing a player move also undoes all triggered auto-moves.

## User Story

As a player, I want cards to automatically move to foundations when it is clearly safe to do so, reducing tedious manual moves and making the game feel polished.

## Acceptance Criteria

- After each player move, the engine checks all tableau columns for cards safe to auto-move to foundations
- Auto-moves execute automatically with a brief animation delay between each
- Undoing a player move also undoes all auto-moves triggered by that move (compound undo via CompoundCommand)
- Auto-move chain is recorded as part of the triggering compound command in UndoRedoManager
- Auto-moves do NOT increment the player's move counter (only player-initiated moves count)
- Unit tests cover safe-move heuristic: cards that are safe and cards that are not safe to auto-move
- `npm test` passes; `npm run build` succeeds

## Open Question

The exact safe-to-auto-move heuristic needs to be defined during implementation. A conservative starting point: a card is safe to auto-move to its foundation if no tableau column contains a card of any suit that has a rank equal to the candidate card's rank minus one (i.e., no column needs this card as a potential build target). The implementer should document the chosen heuristic and test edge cases. Being too aggressive risks moving cards the player needs for tableau building; being too conservative leaves cards the player would prefer auto-moved.

## Minimal Implementation

- Implement `findSafeAutoMoves(state)` function that returns a list of cards safe to move to foundations
- Implement auto-move loop: after each player move, repeatedly call `findSafeAutoMoves()` and execute until no more safe moves exist
- Wrap player move + all triggered auto-moves in a `CompoundCommand` so undo reverses the entire chain
- Add tween animation for each auto-move (brief card flight from column to foundation)
- Ensure auto-moves do not trigger further compound nesting (flat compound)

# Intake Brief: Deploy Card Games to GitHub Pages (CG-0MLTRXRKK1Q50Z0M)

**Priority: Medium** | **Type: Epic** | **Assignee: Map**

> Deploy the Tableau Card Engine's playable example games (9-Card Golf, Beleaguered Castle) to GitHub Pages via an automated GitHub Actions workflow, making them immediately playable in the browser at the default GitHub Pages URL.

## Problem Statement

The Tableau Card Engine has two fully playable example games (9-Card Golf and Beleaguered Castle) that can only be played locally via `npm run dev`. No deployment pipeline or public hosting exists; players and stakeholders must clone the repo and run a local dev server to try the games.

## Users

- **Player / stakeholder (primary):** Wants to play the card games immediately in a browser without any local setup.
  - *"As a player, I want to visit a URL and choose from available card games so I can play them immediately without installing anything."*

- **Project maintainer (secondary):** Wants every merge to `main` to automatically publish the latest version of the games.
  - *"As a maintainer, I want pushes to main to automatically deploy the site so that the published games always reflect the latest state of the code."*

- **Contributor (tertiary):** Wants confidence that only passing builds are deployed.
  - *"As a contributor, I want the deploy pipeline to run tests and build checks before deploying so that broken code never reaches the live site."*

## Success Criteria

1. **Live URL:** Visiting the default GitHub Pages URL (`<user>.github.io/<repo>/`) displays the Game Selector landing page with tiles for 9-Card Golf and Beleaguered Castle.
2. **Automated deployment:** A GitHub Actions workflow automatically builds and deploys the site whenever code is pushed or merged to the `main` branch.
3. **Quality gates enforced:** The workflow runs `npm test` and `npm run build` before deploying; deployment is skipped if either step fails.
4. **Games are playable:** Both 9-Card Golf and Beleaguered Castle are fully playable from the deployed site with all existing functionality intact (input, animations, help panels, scoring, etc.).
5. **Correct asset paths:** All card SVG assets, fonts, and other static resources load correctly under the GitHub Pages sub-path (`/<repo>/`).

## Constraints

- **GitHub Pages only:** The hosting platform is GitHub Pages using the default URL (`<user>.github.io/<repo>/`). No custom domain.
- **Blocked by Game Selector (CG-0MLTRTAWY0X0CSY4):** The deployment depends on the Game Selector Index Page being completed first, since the deployed site needs a landing page to navigate between games.
- **Deploy pipeline scope only:** This work item covers only the GitHub Actions workflow and Vite configuration changes needed for deployment. It does not include PR CI checks, status badges, monitoring, analytics, or error tracking.
- **No Hello World game:** The Hello World example is excluded from the deployed site since it is a toolchain proof, not a playable game.
- **Quality gates:** The project's existing quality gates (`npm test` and `npm run build`) must pass before deployment proceeds.
- **Licensing:** All deployment tooling and configuration must be compatible with the project's open-source licensing requirements.

## Existing State

- **No CI/CD:** No `.github/` directory, no GitHub Actions workflows, no deployment automation of any kind.
- **No hosting configuration:** No references to gh-pages, Netlify, Vercel, or any static hosting in project files. No `gh-pages` npm package.
- **Vite base path not set:** `vite.config.ts` does not configure a `base` path, defaulting to `/`. This is incompatible with GitHub Pages sub-path hosting (`/<repo>/`).
- **No deploy scripts:** `package.json` has no deploy-related scripts.
- **Single hard-coded entry point:** `index.html` is hard-coded to load the Golf game (`/example-games/golf/main.ts`). There is no landing page or game selector.
- **Three example games exist:** hello-world (toolchain proof), 9-Card Golf (playable), Beleaguered Castle (playable). Only Golf and Beleaguered Castle are in scope for deployment.
- **Game Selector in progress:** CG-0MLTRTAWY0X0CSY4 is in-progress on a feature branch but has no commits yet. This deployment epic is blocked until it is completed.

## Desired Change

- **Vite `base` path configuration:** Set `base` in `vite.config.ts` to the repository name (e.g., `/<repo>/`) so that all asset paths resolve correctly on GitHub Pages. This may need to be configurable (e.g., via environment variable) to avoid breaking local development.
- **GitHub Actions workflow (`.github/workflows/deploy.yml` or similar):**
  - Triggered on push to `main` branch.
  - Steps: checkout, install dependencies, run `npm test`, run `npm run build`, deploy `dist/` to GitHub Pages.
  - Uses the official `actions/deploy-pages` action (or `peaceiris/actions-gh-pages` or similar well-maintained action).
- **GitHub Pages configuration:** Enable GitHub Pages in repository settings to serve from the GitHub Actions deployment source. This is a manual step in the GitHub repository settings UI (Settings > Pages > Source: GitHub Actions).
- **Documentation updates:** Update `docs/DEVELOPER.md` and `AGENTS.md` to document the deployment pipeline, the GitHub Pages URL, and the Vite base path configuration.
- **Landing page integration:** The deployed site serves the Game Selector (from CG-0MLTRTAWY0X0CSY4) as the root page, allowing users to choose between 9-Card Golf and Beleaguered Castle.

## Risks & Assumptions

### Risks
- **Vite base path may break local dev:** Changing the Vite `base` to `/<repo>/` could break the local dev server (which expects `/`). Mitigation: use a conditional `base` configuration (e.g., set `base` only for production builds via an environment variable or Vite's `mode`).
- **GitHub Pages caching:** GitHub Pages may aggressively cache assets, causing stale versions to be served after a deploy. Mitigation: Vite's production build uses content-hashed filenames by default, which avoids this for JS/CSS bundles. Verify SVG and other static assets are also handled correctly.
- **Phaser canvas/WebGL on GitHub Pages:** Phaser's WebGL renderer should work on GitHub Pages (it's just static files), but sub-path asset loading issues could cause blank screens or missing card graphics. Mitigation: test the production build locally with `npm run preview` using the correct base path before the first deploy.
- **SPA routing on GitHub Pages:** GitHub Pages serves static files and returns 404 for unknown paths. If the Game Selector uses client-side routing (e.g., `/<repo>/golf`), direct navigation or page refresh on a game URL will 404. Mitigation: verify the Game Selector's routing approach is compatible with static hosting (hash-based routing, or a 404.html fallback).
- **Scope creep into broader CI/CD:** There may be pressure to add PR checks, linting, status badges, or other CI features during this work. Mitigation: record these as separate work items linked to this epic rather than expanding scope.
- **Game Selector dependency delay:** If the Game Selector (CG-0MLTRTAWY0X0CSY4) takes longer than expected, this deployment work will be blocked. Mitigation: the deployment pipeline (workflow, Vite config) can be built and tested independently of the game selector; only the final integration requires it.

### Assumptions
- The GitHub repository has GitHub Pages available (it is a public repo or the account has Pages enabled for private repos).
- The `actions/deploy-pages` (or equivalent) GitHub Action is freely available and well-maintained.
- Vite's production build output (`dist/`) is a self-contained static site suitable for GitHub Pages without server-side processing.
- The Game Selector (CG-0MLTRTAWY0X0CSY4) will produce a single-page application with client-side routing (or direct links) to each game, compatible with GitHub Pages' static file serving model.
- No server-side features (APIs, databases, authentication) are required for the deployed games.

## Related Work

- **Game Selector Index Page (CG-0MLTRTAWY0X0CSY4)** [in-progress]: Prerequisite. This deployment epic is blocked until the game selector landing page is completed. The selector provides the entry point for the deployed site.
- **9-Card Golf (CG-0MLSDW7YM1IWH2SB)** [completed]: First playable game to be included in the deployed site.
- **Beleaguered Castle (CG-0MLSDWFLT1WB6IEB)** [completed]: Second playable game to be included in the deployed site.
- **Scaffold Card Game Engine project (CG-0MLSFU7300TLFCBH)** [completed]: Established the Vite build pipeline and project structure. The deployment work builds on top of this foundation.
- **Add pre-commit hook to enforce doc updates (CG-0MLSHQMDY1H0I2B7)** [open]: The deployment workflow changes must include documentation updates per the doc-update policy.
- **`vite.config.ts`**: Build configuration that needs `base` path changes.
- **`package.json`**: May need a deploy script or updated build configuration.
- **`index.html`**: Current hard-coded entry point that will be replaced by the game selector.
- **`docs/DEVELOPER.md`**: Must be updated with deployment documentation.

## Suggested Next Step

Once the Game Selector (CG-0MLTRTAWY0X0CSY4) is completed, break this epic into child work items: (1) Vite base path configuration, (2) GitHub Actions deploy workflow, (3) GitHub Pages repository settings configuration (manual), (4) documentation updates for `docs/DEVELOPER.md` and `AGENTS.md`, (5) end-to-end deployment verification. Implementation can begin on items 1-2 in parallel with the game selector if desired, with final integration and verification after the selector is merged.

**Dependency:** This epic is blocked by Game Selector Index Page (CG-0MLTRTAWY0X0CSY4). Track with `blocked-by:CG-0MLTRTAWY0X0CSY4`.

## Related work (automated report)

Searched Worklog (keywords: deploy, github, pages, hosting, build, vite, workflow, game selector, CI/CD, base path) and repository files. Conservative filtering applied -- only items with clear relevance to deployment, hosting, or build configuration are included.

### Worklog items

- **Game Selector Index Page (CG-0MLTRTAWY0X0CSY4)** [completed]: The landing page that provides navigation between games. This is the direct prerequisite for deployment -- the deployed site uses this as its root page. Now completed, unblocking this deployment epic.

- **Scaffold Card Game Engine project (CG-0MLSFU7300TLFCBH)** [completed]: Established the Vite 6.1 + TypeScript 5.7 build pipeline, `package.json` scripts (`dev`, `build`, `test`, `preview`), and the project's directory structure. The deployment workflow will invoke the same `npm test` and `npm run build` commands set up by this scaffold. The `vite.config.ts` created here needs `base` path modification for GitHub Pages.

- **Package.json, Vite, and TypeScript Config (CG-0MLSGNJUD0F48DHV)** [completed]: Child of the scaffold epic that created the specific build configuration files (`package.json`, `vite.config.ts`, `tsconfig.json`). The deployment work directly modifies `vite.config.ts` (adding `base` path) and may add a deploy script to `package.json`.

Headline summary
Extract duplicated game logic (Card, Deck, Pile, UI helpers, TurnSequencer, scoring, AI helpers) into stable shared engine modules under `src/` so example games import a single well-tested API and all consumers compile and pass tests after the migration.

Problem statement
Games under `example-games/` duplicate or diverge on core concepts (cards, decks, piles, turn sequencing, scoring). This increases maintenance cost, creates subtle bugs, and makes cross-game tooling harder. We need to refactor and consolidate those components into the engine's `src/` modules and update consumers.

Users
- Engine developers: want stable, well-documented modules they can reuse across spikes. "As an engine developer, I can import `@card-system` and rely on tested Card/Deck/Pile behavior so new game spikes focus on gameplay not plumbing." 
- Example-game authors: want minimal friction migrating to engine APIs. "As a game author, I can update a few imports and run tests to validate my game after the refactor."
- QA/test engineers: want reproducible behaviour and test coverage. "As QA I can run `npm test` and confirm no regressions across example-games after extraction."

Success criteria
1. Card system extraction: `src/card-system` becomes the single canonical implementation (Card, Deck, Pile, index barrel) with new unit tests covering exported behaviour. Example games (Golf, Beleaguered Castle) update imports and pass their tests.
2. Core engine stabilization: `TurnSequencer` and minimal core APIs are refactored as needed, exported from `src/core-engine`, with unit tests and at least one updated consumer integration test passing.
3. All example-games compile and all existing tests (unit + browser tests) pass (`npm test`) after the refactor and consumer updates.
4. Barrel exports and path aliases remain consistent; developer docs updated (`docs/DEVELOPER.md`) with migration notes and examples.
5. No runtime regressions in CI: `npm run build` and `npm test` succeed in CI/local environment.

Constraints
- Policy chosen: allow breaking changes during the refactor and update all example-game consumers in the same sweep (per product decision). This increases scope and requires careful branch/PR coordination.
- All changes must be accompanied by unit tests for exported behaviour and updated consumer tests.
- Keep changes minimal and conservative where possible; where intent is unclear add clarifying questions rather than guessing.
- Ensure `npm test` and `npm run build` succeed before committing; do not push failing branches.

Existing state
- `src/card-system/` currently exists (`Card.ts`, `Deck.ts`, `Pile.ts`, `index.ts`) and is already imported by `example-games/golf` and `example-games/beleaguered-castle`.
- `src/core-engine/TurnSequencer.ts` exists and is used by games, but may need API adjustments.
- Several unit and browser tests exist for card-system and games (`tests/card-system/*`, `tests/golf/*`) — these provide a baseline for expected behaviour and regression checks.
- Worklog context: this item `CG-0MLTSPOK705155TZ` was created and set to in-progress; related work items include the scaffold (CG-0MLSFU7300TLFCBH) and replay tooling (CG-0MLSN2YWY1EL17FN).

Desired change
- Extract and stabilize common modules under `src/` with clear barrel exports and TypeScript types: at minimum `src/card-system`, `src/core-engine` (APIs to be hardened), `src/ui/helpers`, and `src/scoring` or `src/ai` as needed.
- Update all example-game consumers to align with the new/updated APIs (imports, type usages, minor API adjustments). Because breaking changes are allowed (policy), co-update consumers in the same set of PRs.
- Add or update unit tests for each exported module (new tests covering contractual behaviour) and update integration/browser tests for at least the primary consumers.
- Update `docs/DEVELOPER.md` with migration examples and a short checklist for authors.

Related work
- Worklog: `Scaffold Card Game Engine project (CG-0MLSFU7300TLFCBH)` — repo and tooling foundation used by this refactor.
- Worklog: `Game Log Visual Replay Dev Tool (CG-0MLSN2YWY1EL17FN)` — depends on stable engine events and card abstractions.
- Worklog: `Game-Agnostic Replay Adapter Pattern (CG-0MLTFUL061DWDGA2)` — downstream consumer of stable engine APIs.
- Code: `src/card-system/*` — primary extraction target and currently in-use implementation.
- Code: `src/core-engine/TurnSequencer.ts` — candidate for API hardening and tests.
- Tests: `tests/card-system/*`, `tests/golf/*` — baseline tests to verify behaviour after migration.

Suggested next step (implementation plan)
1) Create child work items and branches for each extraction (first: `card-system`), including acceptance criteria and tests. Each child should include: scope, files to move/update, tests to add, and consumer update plan. (This is the immediate next step if you approve the draft.)
2) Implement `card-system` extraction and updates in a dedicated branch: extract & refactor code, add unit tests, update `example-games/golf` and `example-games/beleaguered-castle`, run `npm test` and `npm run build` locally.
3) Repeat for `core-engine` (TurnSequencer), `ui/helpers`, then `scoring`/`ai` modules — each as separate child work items.
4) Create PRs with clear migration notes; run CI and fix issues until `npm test` and `npm run build` pass.

Decision log (from interview)
- Scope & priority: extract `card-system` first, then `TurnSequencer`/core-engine, UI helpers, scoring/AI (user choice: Option A).
- API change policy: allow breaking changes and update all example-games in the same sweep (user choice: Option B).
- Tests & acceptance: require new unit tests for exported behaviour and update all consumers and their tests (user choice: custom).
