# Intake Brief: Game-over screen buttons unresponsive in all games (CG-0MLTSYKYU11LEUWX)

**Priority: High** | **Type: Bug** | **Assignee: Map**

> Game-over overlay buttons (restart, new game, menu) are unresponsive in both Golf and Beleaguered Castle; players must refresh the browser to play again.

## Problem Statement

Text-based interactive buttons on game-over overlay screens are completely unresponsive to pointer/click events in both example games (Golf and Beleaguered Castle). In-game buttons during active gameplay (Menu, Undo, Redo) work correctly, and card interactions (drag-and-drop, click-to-move) also function as expected. The issue is isolated to buttons created on the end-game/game-over overlay screens. After a game ends, the player's only option to start a new game is to refresh the browser page.

## Users

- **Player:** Cannot restart a completed game or navigate back to the game selector menu after a game finishes. Must refresh the browser to play again.
  - *"As a player, I want the restart and menu buttons on the game-over screen to respond when I click them so I can start a new game or return to the game selector without refreshing the browser."*

## Success Criteria

1. Golf end screen buttons respond to clicks: "[ Play Again ]" starts a new game; "[ Menu ]" returns to the game selector.
2. Beleaguered Castle win overlay buttons respond to clicks: "[ New Game ]" starts a new random deal; "[ Restart ]" replays the same deal; "[ Menu ]" returns to the game selector.
3. Beleaguered Castle no-moves overlay buttons respond to clicks: "[ Undo Last ]" dismisses the overlay and undoes the last move; "[ New Game ]", "[ Restart ]", and "[ Menu ]" work as on the win overlay.
4. In-game buttons (Menu, Undo, Redo) continue to work correctly (no regression).
5. Card drag-and-drop and click-to-move interactions continue to work correctly (no regression).
6. All existing tests pass (`npm test`) and build succeeds (`npm run build`).

## Constraints

- The fix must not break in-game buttons, card drag-and-drop, or click-to-move interactions which currently work.
- Both games must be fixed.
- No new dependencies should be required; this is a bug in existing code, not a missing feature.

## Existing State

- **Golf end screen** (`example-games/golf/scenes/GolfScene.ts:671-742`): Creates "[ Play Again ]" and "[ Menu ]" text buttons on a semi-transparent overlay rectangle. Buttons are created with `this.add.text(...).setInteractive({ useHandCursor: true })` and `pointerdown` event handlers. "Play Again" calls `this.scene.restart()`, "Menu" calls `this.scene.start('GameSelectorScene')`. Overlay rectangle is at depth 10, text at depth 11.
- **Beleaguered Castle overlays** (`example-games/beleaguered-castle/scenes/BeleagueredCastleScene.ts:1056-1237`): Creates buttons via `createOverlayButton()` helper (lines 1209-1227) inside a Phaser container at depth 2000. Win overlay has 3 buttons, no-moves overlay has 4 buttons. All buttons use the same `setInteractive({ useHandCursor: true })` pattern.
- **In-game buttons work:** The "[ Menu ]" button, undo/redo buttons, and other HUD elements created during `create()` respond correctly during gameplay, confirming that text `setInteractive()` works in general.
- **Card interactions work:** Phaser's drag system and sprite click interactions function correctly.
- **Prior fix (CG-0MLSW8TKZ0YHXJR2):** A UI interaction bug was previously fixed in the Golf game (commit f251bff, merge 7a007bc). That fix addressed layout/sizing issues.

## Desired Change

Diagnose and fix why text buttons on game-over overlay screens do not receive pointer events. Since in-game buttons work but overlay buttons do not, the root cause is likely related to how the overlay is constructed or how buttons interact with other game objects at game-end time.

Likely causes to investigate:
- **Depth/z-ordering conflict:** The overlay background rectangle or other game objects created at game-end time may be at a higher depth than the buttons, intercepting clicks. In Golf, the overlay rectangle is at depth 10 and text is at depth 11 (these are standalone objects, not in a container). In Beleaguered Castle, buttons are inside a container at depth 2000 -- container children inherit the container's depth for input.
- **Input-blocking game objects:** The `gameEnded` flag or `interactionBlocked` getter in Beleaguered Castle (line 231) may be suppressing input globally, including overlay buttons. In Golf, the `interactionBlocked` equivalent may prevent overlay button events.
- **Container input passthrough:** In Beleaguered Castle, overlay buttons are added to a Phaser Container. If the container doesn't have proper input setup, child interactive objects may not receive events.
- **Hit area sizing:** Text objects may have zero-size or stale hit areas if the text content hasn't been measured by the time `setInteractive()` is called (Phaser quirk with text rendering timing).
- **Overlay rectangle consuming input:** The semi-transparent background rectangles may have been made interactive (explicitly or by default) and are consuming pointer events before they reach the buttons.

After fixing, consider adding automated browser tests that verify end-game overlay button clicks to prevent future regressions.

## Risks & Assumptions

### Risks
- **Different root causes per game:** Although the symptom is identical, Golf uses standalone depth-ordered objects while Beleaguered Castle uses a container-based overlay. The root cause could differ between games, requiring separate fixes.
- **Regression risk:** Changes to depth ordering or input handling could affect in-game button or card interaction behavior.
- **Test coverage gap:** No existing automated tests exercise end-game overlay button clicks. Without new regression tests, this bug class could recur.
- **Input-blocking guard as root cause:** Both games have `interactionBlocked` / guard checks that prevent input during certain states. If the game-end state sets these guards before overlay buttons are created, overlay buttons would inherit the blocked state. This is a high-probability root cause.

### Assumptions
- The issue is in the game code (overlay construction, depth ordering, input blocking logic), not in Phaser 3.90.0 itself.
- In-game buttons working correctly during gameplay confirms the Phaser input system is fundamentally operational.
- The issue is always reproducible and not browser-specific.
- The fix will be straightforward once the root cause (likely depth/input-blocking) is identified.

## Related Work

- **Investigate and fix broken Golf UI interactions (CG-0MLSW8TKZ0YHXJR2)** [completed]: Previous UI fix for the Golf game (commit f251bff, merge 7a007bc). Fixed layout/sizing issues. The overlay buttons may have been introduced or modified after this fix.
- **Win/Loss, New Game, Restart, Scoring (CG-0MLTFF2R70UXJD2T)** [completed]: Implemented the Beleaguered Castle game-over overlays and restart/new-game buttons (commit faa5631, merge 18c373e). This is where the Beleaguered Castle overlay button code was introduced.
- **Golf Phaser UI (CG-0MLSPJ9EW1WGHKLX)** [completed]: Original implementation of the Golf scene including end screen buttons.
- **Phaser UI Browser Testing with Vitest (CG-0MLSUJIE30K54IUO)** [completed]: Browser test infrastructure that could be extended with end-game overlay button-click regression tests.
- **Refactor common components from games into game engine (CG-0MLTSPOK705155TZ)** [open]: Related work to extract shared UI patterns (including overlay buttons) into reusable components. Fixing the button issue first is prerequisite.
- **Game Selector Index Page (CG-0MLTRTAWY0X0CSY4)** [completed]: The menu navigation target for "[ Menu ]" buttons.


## Related work (automated report)

Searched Worklog (68 items, keywords: game-over, overlay, button, unresponsive, restart, input, interactive, pointer, depth, setInteractive, interactionBlocked, gameEnded) and repository files. The following items have clear, direct relevance to the game-over button unresponsiveness bug.

### Worklog items

- **Investigate and fix broken Golf UI interactions (CG-0MLSW8TKZ0YHXJR2)** [completed]: The most directly relevant prior fix. Addressed broken Golf UI layout and click handling (commit f251bff, merge 7a007bc) by resizing cards and recalculating layout positions. The fix focused on in-game interactions rather than end-screen overlays, so overlay buttons may not have been tested after those layout changes. The same class of problem (pointer events not reaching targets) recurs here in the overlay context.

- **Win/Loss, New Game, Restart, Scoring (CG-0MLTFF2R70UXJD2T)** [completed]: Introduced the Beleaguered Castle game-over overlay code (commit faa5631, merge 18c373e), including the `gameEnded` flag, `interactionBlocked` getter, `showWinOverlay()`, `showNoMovesOverlay()`, and `createOverlayButton()`. This is the origin of the Beleaguered Castle side of the bug. The `interactionBlocked` getter returns `true` when `gameEnded` is `true` (line 232), which gates all card and drag interaction handlers -- but overlay button handlers are separate and should not be affected unless the overlay is constructed before buttons are interactive.

- **Golf Phaser UI (CG-0MLSPJ9EW1WGHKLX)** [completed]: Original implementation of the Golf scene including the `showEndScreen()` method (lines 671-742). The end screen creates a depth-10 overlay rectangle and depth-11 text buttons as standalone objects (not in a container). The overlay rectangle is not explicitly made interactive, but Phaser may still intercept pointer events on it if its hit area overlaps the buttons.

- **Phaser UI Browser Testing with Vitest (CG-0MLSUJIE30K54IUO)** [completed]: Established the Playwright + Vitest browser test infrastructure (headless Chromium, `*.browser.test.ts` convention). Existing browser tests cover in-game interactions but do not exercise end-game overlay buttons. This infrastructure should be extended with regression tests for overlay button clicks as part of the fix.

- **Game Selector Index Page (CG-0MLTRTAWY0X0CSY4)** [completed]: Added `[ Menu ]` buttons to both game scenes (commit 40ca574, merge 7f315fb), including overlay menu buttons. The menu button is the navigation target for overlay `[ Menu ]` buttons (`this.scene.start('GameSelectorScene')`). Relevant because the Menu button implementation in overlays was added/modified in this work item.

- **Refactor common components from games into game engine (CG-0MLTSPOK705155TZ)** [open]: Plans to extract shared UI patterns including overlay buttons into reusable engine components. Fixing the overlay button bug is a prerequisite for this extraction -- the extracted component must work correctly.

- **In-Game Transcript Export Button (CG-0MLTFRU211Y0Z2WU)** [open]: Plans to add an "Export Transcript" button to the end-of-round results screen. This feature depends on overlay buttons being functional, as the export button would be added to the same overlay that is currently unresponsive.

- **Beleaguered Castle (CG-0MLSDWFLT1WB6IEB)** [completed]: Parent epic for the Beleaguered Castle game. The `interactionBlocked` guard pattern (line 231) and `gameEnded` flag (line 208) were introduced across multiple child features. Understanding how these flags interact with overlay button input is key to diagnosing the Beleaguered Castle side of the bug.

### Repository files

- **`example-games/golf/scenes/GolfScene.ts`** (lines 671-742): Contains `showEndScreen()` which creates the Golf end-game overlay. Overlay rectangle at depth 10, text buttons at depth 11. Buttons use `setInteractive({ useHandCursor: true })` with `pointerdown` handlers. The overlay rectangle is not explicitly interactive but may block input. Key code for diagnosing the Golf side of the bug.

- **`example-games/beleaguered-castle/scenes/BeleagueredCastleScene.ts`** (lines 1056-1237): Contains `showWinOverlay()`, `showNoMovesOverlay()`, and `createOverlayButton()`. Overlay buttons are inside a Phaser Container at depth 2000. The `interactionBlocked` getter (line 231) returns `true` when `gameEnded` is `true`, gating all card/drag handlers (lines 479, 507, 520, 539, 752, 776, 807, 907, 917). However, overlay button `pointerdown` handlers are registered directly on text objects and do not check `interactionBlocked` -- so the guard should not block them unless Phaser's container input system is involved.

- **`example-games/beleaguered-castle/scenes/BeleagueredCastleScene.ts`** (line 208, 231-232): The `gameEnded` boolean and `interactionBlocked` getter. When `gameEnded` is set to `true` (lines 940, 951, 1025), `interactionBlocked` returns `true`, blocking card interactions. The overlays are shown after `gameEnded` is set. If `interactionBlocked` inadvertently blocks overlay button input (e.g., through a global input check), this is likely the root cause for Beleaguered Castle.

- **`src/ui/HelpPanel.ts`** (line 432): Uses `this.inputBlocker.setInteractive()` to create an input-blocking overlay. This is a working example of an interactive overlay that intentionally blocks input behind it. The game-over overlays may need a similar pattern but currently lack it, or conversely, the HelpPanel's input blocker may be interfering.

- **`src/ui/GameSelectorScene.ts`** (line 157): Uses `setInteractive({ useHandCursor: true })` for game card buttons on the selector page. These buttons work correctly, confirming the pattern is valid when no input-blocking guards are active.

## Summary

Configure Vite's `base` option in `vite.config.ts` so that all asset paths resolve correctly when the site is served from a GitHub Pages sub-path (`/Tableau-Card-Engine/`).

## User Story

As a maintainer, I want the production build to use the correct base path for GitHub Pages so that all JavaScript bundles, CSS, and card SVG assets load correctly from `<user>.github.io/Tableau-Card-Engine/`.

## Current State

- `vite.config.ts` has no `base` option set (defaults to `/`)
- Game scenes load card SVGs using relative paths: `assets/cards/card_back.svg` (no leading `/`)
- Local dev server at `http://localhost:3000` works with the default `/` base

## Implementation Approach

1. Add a conditional `base` to `vite.config.ts`:
   - In production mode (`mode === 'production'`): set `base: '/Tableau-Card-Engine/'`
   - In development mode: keep `base: '/'` (default)
   - Use Vite's `defineConfig` function form that accepts a `mode` parameter
2. Run `npm run build` and inspect `dist/index.html` to verify asset paths include the base prefix
3. Run `npm run preview` and verify the production build still works (note: preview will serve at `/`, not `/Tableau-Card-Engine/`, so asset paths in the HTML should be checked manually)
4. Ensure `npm test` still passes

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] `vite.config.ts` sets `base: '/Tableau-Card-Engine/'` for production builds
- [ ] `vite.config.ts` keeps `base: '/'` for development (`npm run dev` still works at localhost:3000)
- [ ] `npm run build` succeeds and `dist/index.html` references assets with the `/Tableau-Card-Engine/` prefix
- [ ] `npm test` passes
- [ ] No hardcoded absolute asset paths exist in game scenes (they use relative paths already -- verify this remains the case)

## Summary

Create a GitHub Actions workflow file (`.github/workflows/deploy.yml`) that automatically builds and deploys the site to GitHub Pages whenever code is pushed to the `main` branch.

## User Story

As a maintainer, I want pushes to main to automatically deploy the site so that the published games always reflect the latest state of the code without manual intervention.

As a contributor, I want the deploy pipeline to run tests and build checks before deploying so that broken code never reaches the live site.

## Current State

- No `.github/` directory exists
- No CI/CD workflows of any kind
- Build and test commands exist: `npm test` and `npm run build`

## Implementation Approach

1. Create `.github/workflows/deploy.yml` with the following structure:
   - **Trigger:** `push` to `main` branch only
   - **Permissions:** `contents: read`, `pages: write`, `id-token: write` (for OIDC token-based Pages deployment)
   - **Concurrency:** Use `concurrency` group to cancel in-flight deploys when a new push arrives
   - **Job: build-and-deploy:**
     - `actions/checkout@v4`
     - `actions/setup-node@v4` with Node.js 20
     - `npm ci` (clean install for reproducibility)
     - `npx playwright install chromium` (needed for browser tests)
     - `npm test` (quality gate -- fail the workflow if tests fail)
     - `npm run build` (quality gate -- fail if build fails)
     - `actions/upload-pages-artifact@v3` pointing at `dist/`
     - `actions/deploy-pages@v4` to deploy to GitHub Pages
2. Use the official `actions/deploy-pages` action (not `peaceiris/actions-gh-pages`) since it integrates with GitHub's Pages deployment API and doesn't require a PAT or deploy key
3. Add an `environment` block for `github-pages` with the deployment URL

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] `.github/workflows/deploy.yml` exists and is valid YAML
- [ ] Workflow triggers on push to `main` branch only
- [ ] Workflow installs dependencies with `npm ci`
- [ ] Workflow installs Playwright Chromium for browser tests
- [ ] Workflow runs `npm test` before building (fails workflow if tests fail)
- [ ] Workflow runs `npm run build` (fails workflow if build fails)
- [ ] Workflow uploads `dist/` as a Pages artifact
- [ ] Workflow deploys to GitHub Pages using `actions/deploy-pages@v4`
- [ ] Concurrency group prevents parallel deployments
- [ ] No secrets or tokens are required (uses OIDC)

# Intake Brief: Golf Animation is Confusing (CG-0MLTW1ZU40CQ7387)

**Priority: Medium** | **Type: Bug** | **Assignee: Map**

> Fix the Golf card swap and discard-and-flip animations so that card movements are visually clear — grid cards reveal their face before departing, drawn cards visually travel to their destination, and both players' turns use the same improved animations.

## Problem Statement

In the 9-Card Golf game, the card swap animation is confusing: when a player swaps a drawn card with a grid card, the grid card does a flip-in-place and its texture is simply replaced with the drawn card. The old grid card never visually moves to the discard pile and the drawn card never visually moves to the grid slot, making it unclear what just happened. The same issue affects both the swap and discard-and-flip move types.

## Users

- **Player (primary):** Plays Golf in the browser and needs clear visual feedback about what is happening during card swaps and flips.
  - *"As a player, I want to see the grid card flip to reveal its face and then move to the discard pile while the drawn card slides into the grid slot, so I can clearly understand what just happened."*

- **Engine developer:** Maintains the GolfScene animation code and needs it to be clear, maintainable, and consistent across move types.
  - *"As a developer, I want the animation logic for swap and discard-and-flip to be clearly structured so I can extend or adjust timings without confusion."*

## Success Criteria

1. **Swap animation:** When a swap move occurs, the grid card flips (revealing its face) while simultaneously moving to the discard pile, and the drawn card simultaneously animates from its display position into the now-vacated grid slot.
2. **Discard-and-flip animation:** When a discard-and-flip move occurs, the drawn card animates from its display position to the discard pile, then the selected face-down grid card flips in place to reveal itself.
3. **Both players:** The improved animations play for both human and AI turns.
4. **No regressions:** All existing unit and browser tests pass (`npm test`), and `npm run build` succeeds.
5. **Playable:** A complete round of Golf can be played from start to finish in the browser without animation glitches or unhandled errors.

## Constraints

- Scope is limited to the card swap/flip animation fix. No other visual polish or feature changes are included.
- Animations must use Phaser tweens (the existing animation framework in the project).
- The fix must work for both human and AI player turns.
- Card asset dimensions remain 140x190px.

## Existing State

The animation code lives in `GolfScene.ts:588-636` in the `animateTurn()` method. Currently:

- **Swap move:** The grid card sprite scales X to 0 (half-flip), then its texture is changed to the incoming drawn card, then it scales X back to 1. The old grid card texture is replaced in-place — there is no movement animation of either card.
- **Discard-and-flip move:** Identical animation to swap — the grid card flips and its texture changes. No visual movement of the drawn card to the discard pile.
- The drawn card display is handled by `showDrawnCard()` (line 641) and `hideDrawnCard()` (line 660), which create/destroy a sprite near the discard pile.

## Desired Change

Modify the `animateTurn()` method in `GolfScene.ts` to implement two distinct animation sequences:

### Swap move
1. The grid card begins a flip animation (scale X 0→1 with texture change to reveal its actual face) while simultaneously translating from the grid slot position toward the discard pile position.
2. At the same time, the drawn card sprite translates from its display position (right of discard pile) into the grid slot position.
3. Both movements happen simultaneously (parallel tweens).
4. On completion, update the discard pile visual and refresh the grid.

### Discard-and-flip move
1. The drawn card sprite animates from its display position to the discard pile position.
2. After that animation completes, the selected face-down grid card flips in place (scale X 0→1 with texture change to reveal its face).
3. On completion, update the discard pile visual and refresh the grid.

## Related Work

- **Golf Phaser UI (CG-0MLSPJ9EW1WGHKLX)** [completed]: Original implementation that created the current animation code.
- **Investigate and fix broken Golf UI interactions (CG-0MLSW8TKZ0YHXJR2)** [completed]: Previous bug fix for Golf UI interactions.
- **9-Card Golf (CG-0MLSDW7YM1IWH2SB)** [completed]: Parent epic for all Golf game work.
- **Golf Scene Event Integration (CG-0MLTFSPNA1WUN7MS)** [blocked]: Future event-driven scene work that may consume or interact with animation code.

## Risks & Assumptions

### Risks
- **Animation timing complexity:** Coordinating simultaneous flip + translate + movement tweens may require careful sequencing to avoid visual glitches. Mitigation: test with both fast and slow animation durations; use Phaser's built-in tween chaining/parallel capabilities.
- **AI turn visibility:** AI turns happen with a delay (`AI_DELAY`); the new longer animations may need timing adjustments so the AI turn doesn't feel too slow or overlap with the next turn. Mitigation: test AI turns visually during development and adjust `AI_DELAY` if needed.
- **Scope creep:** Improving animations could lead to desire for additional visual polish (particle effects, sound, card arc paths, etc.). Mitigation: record any opportunities for additional features or refinements as separate work items linked via `discovered-from:CG-0MLTW1ZU40CQ7387`, rather than expanding the scope of this item.
- **Browser test brittleness:** Existing browser tests (`GolfScene.browser.test.ts`, `GolfInteraction.browser.test.ts`, `GolfOverlay.browser.test.ts`) may assert animation timing or sprite positions that break with the new animation sequences. Mitigation: review and update browser tests as part of the implementation.

### Assumptions
- Phaser 3.90.0's tween system supports running simultaneous translate + scale tweens on different sprites without conflicts.
- The existing `showDrawnCard()`/`hideDrawnCard()` pattern can be adapted to animate the drawn card sprite to its destination rather than just creating/destroying it.
- No changes are needed to the game logic (`GolfRules`, `GolfGame`, etc.) — this is purely a visual/animation fix in `GolfScene.ts`.
- The `hideDrawnCard()` call currently in `humanMove()` (line 510) will need to be deferred or restructured so the drawn card sprite persists long enough to animate.

# Intake Brief: Sound Engine & Golf Game Audio (CG-0MLUDH5JH05H3D9J)

**Priority: Medium** | **Type: Feature** | **Assignee: Map**

> Build a reusable, Phaser-agnostic SoundManager in the core engine, extend GameEventEmitter with card-level events, and wire 8+ sound effects into the Golf game to validate the audio system end-to-end.

## Problem Statement

The Tableau Card Engine has zero audio support -- no sound manager, no audio assets, no Phaser audio configuration, and no card-level events in the GameEventEmitter. Games built on the engine feel flat and unresponsive without auditory feedback. A reusable sound system is needed in the core engine so that any example game can add audio cues without reimplementing sound infrastructure.

## Users

- **Player:** Wants responsive audio feedback during gameplay to reinforce actions and understand game state.
  - *"As a player, I want to hear distinct sounds when I draw, flip, swap, and discard cards so that the game feels polished and I get immediate feedback on my actions."*
  - *"As a player, I want to control sound volume and mute audio from an in-game settings panel so I can adjust the experience to my preference."*

- **Engine developer:** Wants a reusable sound module that integrates with the existing event system and follows the project's Phaser-agnostic patterns.
  - *"As an engine developer, I want a SoundManager in the core engine that subscribes to GameEventEmitter events and auto-plays mapped sounds so that adding audio to a new game is a configuration step, not a re-implementation."*
  - *"As an engine developer, I want card-level events (card-drawn, card-flipped, card-swapped, card-discarded) added to GameEventEmitter so that any system -- audio, analytics, replay -- can react to granular gameplay actions."*

## Success Criteria

1. A `SoundManager` class exists in `src/core-engine/`, exported from the barrel file, following the Phaser-agnostic interface pattern (like `PhaserEventBridge`). It provides: register sound by key, play by key, stop, mute/unmute toggle, and volume control (0.0--1.0).
2. `GameEventEmitter` is extended with 5 new events: `card-drawn`, `card-flipped`, `card-swapped`, `card-discarded`, and `ui-interaction`, with typed payloads. Existing events and consumers are unaffected.
3. `SoundManager` can subscribe to `GameEventEmitter` events via a declarative event-to-sound mapping configuration, automatically playing the mapped sound when the event fires.
4. The Golf game emits the new card-level events at the appropriate moments and loads/plays at least 8 distinct SFX: card-draw, card-flip, card-swap, card-discard, turn-change, round-end, score-reveal, and ui-click.
5. Mute preference persists across page reloads via localStorage.
6. All audio assets are .mp3 format, CC0 or permissively licensed, stored under `public/assets/audio/`, and attributed in `public/assets/CREDITS.md`.
7. Unit tests cover SoundManager core logic (registration, play-by-key, mute/unmute, volume, event-to-sound mapping). `npm test` passes and `npm run build` succeeds.
8. A settings panel with mute toggle and volume slider is delivered as a separate child work item with its own acceptance criteria.

## Constraints

- **Phaser-agnostic interface:** SoundManager must follow the same dependency-injection pattern as `PhaserEventBridge` -- define a minimal `SoundPlayer` interface (play, stop, volume, mute), inject Phaser's sound manager at runtime. No compile-time Phaser imports in `src/core-engine/`.
- **Browser autoplay policy:** Audio playback requires user interaction before the Web Audio API context is unlocked. The implementation must handle this gracefully (Phaser 3 handles this internally, but it should be verified).
- **Licensing:** All audio assets must be CC0, MIT, Apache 2.0, or similarly permissive per project policy.
- **SFX only:** Background music is out of scope. The SoundManager API should not preclude adding it later, but no looping/music features are required.
- **File format:** .mp3 only. No need for .ogg fallbacks.
- **Backward compatibility:** The 5 new GameEventEmitter events must be additive. Existing event consumers and tests must not break.

## Existing State

- **Core engine** (`src/core-engine/`): 7 modules including GameEventEmitter (5 lifecycle events), PhaserEventBridge, TurnSequencer, UndoRedoManager, TranscriptStore. All Phaser-agnostic except the bridge's injected dependency.
- **GameEventEmitter events:** `turn-started`, `turn-completed`, `animation-complete`, `state-settled`, `game-ended`. No card-level or UI-interaction events.
- **Golf game** (`example-games/golf/`): Fully playable 9-Card Golf (human vs. AI) with ~10 natural SFX trigger points in `GolfScene.ts` (draw, flip, swap, discard, AI turn, round end, etc.). Currently silent.
- **UI module** (`src/ui/`): 10 reusable components including HelpPanel (slide-out overlay), HelpButton, OverlayButton, MenuButton. No settings panel exists.
- **Audio assets:** None. No `public/assets/audio/` directory. No audio configuration in Phaser game config.

## Desired Change

### Core Engine (`src/core-engine/`)
- New `SoundManager.ts` module with Phaser-agnostic interface:
  - `SoundPlayer` interface (minimal: `play(key)`, `stop(key)`, `setVolume(v)`, `setMute(m)`)
  - `SoundManager` class: register sounds, play by key, mute/unmute, volume control, event-to-sound mapping via `GameEventEmitter` subscription
  - Mute/volume persistence via localStorage
  - Exported from `src/core-engine/index.ts`
- Extend `GameEventEmitter` with 5 new typed events:
  - `card-drawn` (source: stock/discard, playerIndex)
  - `card-flipped` (position, playerIndex)
  - `card-swapped` (position, drawnFrom, playerIndex)
  - `card-discarded` (playerIndex)
  - `ui-interaction` (elementId, action)

### Golf Game (`example-games/golf/`)
- Emit new card-level events from `GolfScene.ts` at appropriate action points
- Load 8+ SFX assets in scene preload
- Configure event-to-sound mapping via SoundManager
- Wire SoundManager into the Phaser scene lifecycle (init with scene's sound manager, cleanup on shutdown)

### Audio Assets
- Source 8+ CC0 .mp3 sound effects and store in `public/assets/audio/`
- Update `public/assets/CREDITS.md` with attribution

### Settings Panel (child work item)
- A reusable engine-level settings panel (slide-out, modelled after HelpPanel) with mute toggle and volume slider. This will be tracked as a separate child work item under this one, with sections for engine-wide settings (sound) and placeholder structure for future game-specific settings.

## Risks & Assumptions

### Risks
- **Browser autoplay:** Web Audio context may be locked until user interaction. Phaser 3 internally handles context unlocking, but this must be verified on mobile browsers. Mitigation: test on Chrome, Firefox, Safari mobile.
- **CC0 SFX quality:** Finding 8+ consistent-quality CC0 card game sound effects may require effort. Mitigation: Kenney.nl asset packs and freesound.org have large CC0 collections suitable for card games.
- **Event backward compatibility:** Adding 5 new events to GameEventEmitter could affect existing consumers if event names collide. Mitigation: use namespaced, descriptive event names; verify no existing code listens for these names.
- **PhaserEventBridge scope:** The existing PhaserEventBridge forwards only the current 5 lifecycle events. Adding 5 new events will require updating the bridge to forward them too, or the SoundManager must subscribe directly to the engine emitter (not via Phaser scene events). Mitigation: decide during implementation which approach is cleaner.
- **Audio asset file size:** Multiple .mp3 files increase initial page load. Mitigation: keep SFX short (< 2s, < 50KB each); consider lazy-loading or Phaser's audio sprite support if bundle size becomes an issue.

### Assumptions
- Phaser 3.90.0's `WebAudioSoundManager` is sufficient; no additional audio libraries are needed.
- Short .mp3 sound effects (< 2 seconds each) are adequate for all required SFX.
- The existing `GameEventEmitter` architecture supports adding new events without breaking changes (it's a typed map, so new keys are additive).
- The settings panel child work item can be developed and merged independently of the core SoundManager work.
- The SoundManager subscribes to the engine-side `GameEventEmitter` directly, not through the PhaserEventBridge, keeping audio triggering Phaser-agnostic.

## Related Work

- **9-Card Golf** (CG-0MLSDW7YM1IWH2SB) [completed]: Parent epic; this sound work was discovered during its implementation.
- **Core Engine Event System** (CG-0MLTFSAOM1W4UKI8) [completed]: Established GameEventEmitter; this work item extends it with card-level events.
- **Golf Scene Event Integration** (CG-0MLTFSPNA1WUN7MS) [completed]: Wired lifecycle events into Golf scene; this work item adds card-level event emission.
- **Refactor common components from games into game engine** (CG-0MLTSPOK705155TZ) [completed]: Established patterns for extracting reusable components to `src/ui/`; the settings panel follows this pattern.
- **HelpPanel Core Component** (CG-0MLTANMZ80E1GY0X) [completed]: The settings panel design is modelled after HelpPanel's slide-out UX.
- `src/core-engine/PhaserEventBridge.ts`: Design pattern (Phaser-agnostic interface + runtime injection) that SoundManager should follow.
- `src/core-engine/GameEventEmitter.ts`: Primary integration point; will be extended with 5 new events.
- `example-games/golf/scenes/GolfScene.ts`: Primary SFX integration target (~10 trigger points).

## Suggested Next Step

Break CG-0MLUDH5JH05H3D9J into child tasks: (1) Extend GameEventEmitter with new card-level events, (2) Implement SoundManager module, (3) Source CC0 audio assets, (4) Integrate SFX into Golf game, (5) Build settings panel (child work item). Then proceed to planning and implementation per `wl next`.

## Related work (automated report)

Searched Worklog (keywords: sound, audio, sfx, SoundManager, GameEventEmitter, event, PhaserEventBridge, HelpPanel, settings, volume, mute, card-drawn, card-flipped, golf) and repository files for items related to CG-0MLUDH5JH05H3D9J.

### Worklog items

- **Golf animation is confusing (CG-0MLTW1ZU40CQ7387)** [completed]: This item's risks section explicitly identified "sound" as a potential follow-on feature discovered during animation improvements. The SoundManager work was anticipated as scope expansion from this animation polish effort, confirming the lineage between animation and audio feedback improvements.

- **Undo/Redo Module (CG-0MLTFC94Z00K32ZI)** [completed]: Established the command pattern and `UndoRedoManager` in `src/core-engine/`. The SoundManager follows the same Phaser-agnostic module pattern for `src/core-engine/` and must be exported from the same barrel file. The UndoRedoManager's architecture (engine module with no Phaser compile-time dependency) is the direct precedent for SoundManager's design.

- **Extract game overlay and button system to src/ui/ (CG-0MLU874O10DAKCZZ)** [completed]: Extracted `Overlay`, `OverlayButton`, and `MenuButton` into reusable `src/ui/` components. The settings panel child work item will consume these same UI primitives (overlay background, styled buttons) and follow the same extraction pattern.

- **Game Log Visual Replay Dev Tool (CG-0MLSN2YWY1EL17FN)** [in-progress]: The replay tool subscribes to `GameEventEmitter` lifecycle events for screenshot synchronization. The 5 new card-level events added by this work item could enable finer-grained replay capture (per-card-action screenshots). The replay tool's `PhaserEventBridge` integration also validates the bridge-forwarding pattern that SoundManager's event subscription will parallel.

- **Beleaguered Castle (CG-0MLSDWFLT1WB6IEB)** [completed]: Second completed game spike. Once SoundManager is implemented and proven in Golf, Beleaguered Castle would be the natural second consumer for audio integration, validating the reusability of the SoundManager's event-to-sound mapping across different game types.

- **In-Game Transcript Export Button (CG-0MLTFRU211Y0Z2WU)** [open]: Adds a UI button to the end-of-round overlay. The settings panel child work item will use the same UI component patterns (overlay buttons, scene integration). Both items extend the in-game UI surface and may share layout considerations.

### Repository files

- **`src/core-engine/GameEventEmitter.ts`**: Contains the typed `GameEventMap` interface (currently 5 lifecycle events) and `GameEventEmitter` class. This file must be extended with 5 new card-level event types (`card-drawn`, `card-flipped`, `card-swapped`, `card-discarded`, `ui-interaction`) and their typed payloads. The existing typed map pattern (lines 86-92) makes additive extension straightforward.

The SoundManager must follow this same Phaser-agnostic dependency-injection pattern: define a minimal `SoundPlayer` interface, accept a concrete implementation at runtime. The bridge also forwards events between engine and Phaser — the new card-level events may need forwarding decisions.

The settings panel child work item is explicitly modelled after HelpPanel's architecture (panel container, slide animation, close button, content sections). Understanding HelpPanel's API (`HelpPanelConfig`, `HelpSection`) is essential for designing the settings panel.

Currently creates `GameEventEmitter` and `PhaserEventBridge` instances (lines 139-140) — the SoundManager will be instantiated alongside these. # Intake Brief: Add Medieval-Themed Sound Effects to Beleaguered Castle

**Priority: Medium** | **Type: Feature (Epic)** | **Assignee: TBD**

> Add a full set of medieval/castle-themed sound effects to the Beleaguered Castle solitaire game using the existing Sound Engine infrastructure (GameEventEmitter, SoundManager, PhaserEventBridge, SettingsPanel), with new Tone.js-generated audio assets and new solitaire-specific event types.

## Problem Statement

The Beleaguered Castle game is fully playable but completely silent. The Golf game already has sound effects integrated via the Sound Engine (SoundManager, GameEventEmitter, PhaserEventBridge), a SettingsPanel with mute/volume controls, and 8 procedurally generated WAV files. However, Beleaguered Castle has zero audio integration -- no event emitter, no sound manager, no audio preloading, and no settings panel. Adding themed sound effects will significantly improve the player experience, provide feedback for card interactions, and validate that the Sound Engine is reusable across multiple games.

## Users

- **Player (primary):** Wants audible feedback when interacting with cards -- picking up, placing, invalid moves, winning, losing -- to make the game feel more polished and responsive.
  - *"As a player, I want to hear satisfying medieval-themed sounds when I move cards, complete foundations, and win or lose, so the game feels immersive and gives me clear audio feedback on my actions."*

- **Engine developer:** Wants to validate that the Sound Engine (SoundManager, GameEventEmitter, SettingsPanel) is truly reusable across games without significant modification.
  - *"As an engine developer, I want to integrate the Sound Engine into a second game to confirm the architecture is game-agnostic and identify any missing abstractions."*

## Success Criteria

1. **All 12-15 sound trigger points have audio:** Card pickup, foundation drop, tableau drop, snap-back (invalid move), deal animation, win fanfare, loss sound, auto-complete cascade start, auto-complete card landing, undo, redo, card selection (click-to-move), deselection, and UI button clicks all produce distinct sound effects.
2. **Medieval/castle theme:** All sounds have a medieval/castle aesthetic -- deeper stone-like thuds for card placement, metallic chimes for foundation completions, brass-like fanfare for wins, heavy gate-closing for losses, etc. Sounds are clearly distinct from the Golf game's set.
3. **Tone.js synthesis:** All new audio assets are generated procedurally using Tone.js in a one-off Node.js script (not the existing `generate-sfx.mjs`). Output is WAV files saved to `public/assets/audio/beleaguered-castle/` (or a sub-directory structure). All generated sounds are CC0/public domain since they are synthesized from scratch.
4. **Event-driven architecture:** Sounds are triggered via GameEventEmitter events, not direct `soundManager.play()` calls. The BeleagueredCastleScene emits events at all action points, and an EventSoundMapping configuration binds events to sounds.
5. **New solitaire event types:** GameEventEmitter is extended with new event types for solitaire-specific mechanics: `card-to-foundation`, `card-to-tableau`, `card-pickup`, `card-snap-back`, `auto-complete-start`, `auto-complete-card`, `undo`, `redo`, `card-selected`, `card-deselected`, and `deal-card`. These are added to the shared `GameEventMap` so other solitaire games can reuse them.
6. **SettingsPanel integrated:** The existing SettingsPanel (mute toggle + volume slider) is added to the Beleaguered Castle scene, providing consistent audio controls matching the Golf game.
7. **All tests pass:** `npm test` passes, `npm run build` succeeds. New unit tests cover the new event types and sound mapping configuration.
8. **Asset attribution:** `public/assets/CREDITS.md` updated with attribution for the new Tone.js-generated sounds (CC0, synthesized procedurally).

## Constraints

- **Tone.js as a one-off script dependency:** Tone.js must be added as a devDependency (`npm install --save-dev tone`). It is used only in a generation script, not bundled into the game runtime. The game loads pre-generated WAV files at runtime, identical to the existing Golf pattern.
- **No changes to existing Golf sounds:** The Golf game's existing 8 WAV files and sound integration must remain unchanged and functional.
- **Reuse existing Sound Engine:** The SoundManager, PhaserEventBridge, and SettingsPanel must be used as-is. If modifications are needed, they must be backward-compatible with the Golf game's integration.
- **Shared GameEventEmitter:** New event types are added to the shared `GameEventMap` in `src/core-engine/GameEventEmitter.ts`, not in a game-specific emitter. This ensures reusability for future solitaire games.
- **Licensing:** All generated sounds must be CC0/public domain (guaranteed by procedural synthesis). Tone.js itself is MIT-licensed.
- **Quality gates:** `npm test` and `npm run build` must pass before any merge.

## Existing State

- **Sound Engine (complete, proven in Golf):**
  - `src/core-engine/SoundManager.ts` -- Phaser-agnostic SoundManager with DI (`SoundPlayer` interface), `EventSoundMapping` type, localStorage persistence for mute/volume
  - `src/core-engine/GameEventEmitter.ts` -- 10 event types (5 lifecycle + 5 card-level: `card-drawn`, `card-flipped`, `card-swapped`, `card-discarded`, `ui-interaction`)
  - `src/core-engine/PhaserEventBridge.ts` -- Bidirectional bridge between GameEventEmitter and Phaser.Events
  - `src/ui/SettingsPanel.ts` -- Mute toggle + volume slider, tested (11 tests)
  - `src/ui/SettingsButton.ts` -- Gear icon button
  - 8 WAV files in `public/assets/audio/` (card-draw, card-flip, card-swap, card-discard, turn-change, round-end, score-reveal, ui-click)
  - `scripts/generate-sfx.mjs` -- Existing procedural WAV generator (uses audiobuffer-to-wav, Node.js only)

- **Beleaguered Castle (complete, no audio):**
  - `example-games/beleaguered-castle/scenes/BeleagueredCastleScene.ts` -- 1488-line main scene with drag-and-drop, click-to-move, auto-complete, undo/redo, win/loss overlays, help panel
  - `example-games/beleaguered-castle/createBeleagueredCastleGame.ts` -- Phaser game config (needs `audio: { disableWebAudio: false }`)
  - `example-games/beleaguered-castle/BeleagueredCastleRules.ts` -- Pure game logic
  - Key interaction points identified for SFX triggers (see Desired Change below)

- **Golf game (reference implementation):**
  - Pattern: define `SFX_KEYS` constants -> preload audio -> create `SoundPlayer` wrapper -> create `SoundManager` -> register SFX -> declare `EventSoundMapping` -> emit events at action points -> create `SettingsPanel` -> cleanup on shutdown

## Desired Change

### 1. Extend GameEventEmitter with solitaire events
Add new event types to `src/core-engine/GameEventEmitter.ts`:
- `card-to-foundation` -- card placed on a foundation pile (with suit, rank payload)
- `card-to-tableau` -- card placed on a tableau column
- `card-pickup` -- card picked up (drag start or click-to-move selection)
- `card-snap-back` -- invalid move, card returns to original position
- `auto-complete-start` -- auto-complete cascade begins
- `auto-complete-card` -- individual card auto-completed to foundation
- `undo` -- undo action performed
- `redo` -- redo action performed
- `card-selected` -- card selected via click-to-move
- `card-deselected` -- card deselected (click elsewhere or different card)
- `deal-card` -- card dealt during initial deal animation

Add corresponding payload interfaces. Unit tests for the new event types.

### 2. Generate medieval-themed Tone.js sound effects
Create a new script (e.g., `scripts/generate-castle-sfx.ts` or `.mjs`) using Tone.js to procedurally synthesize ~12-15 WAV files:
- **card-pickup:** Stone scrape / heavy lift (short, textured noise burst with low resonance)
- **card-to-foundation:** Metallic bell chime (bright, ascending, celebratory)
- **card-to-tableau:** Stone thud / heavy placement (deep, short, satisfying)
- **card-snap-back:** Wooden clunk / rejection (dull, low, short -- "nope")
- **deal-card:** Quick stone slide / parchment shuffle (repeated during deal stagger)
- **win-fanfare:** Triumphant brass-like ascending fanfare (3-5 notes, majestic)
- **loss-sound:** Deep descending tone / heavy gate closing (somber)
- **auto-complete-start:** Ascending sparkle / magic activation
- **auto-complete-card:** Quick bright chime (plays rapidly during cascade, so must be very short; consider slight pitch variation per card for a musical cascade effect)
- **undo:** Reverse swoosh / rewind sound
- **redo:** Forward swoosh (opposite of undo)
- **card-select:** Soft metallic click / highlight
- **card-deselect:** Softer inverse of select
- **ui-click:** Castle-themed button press (stone or iron)

Output to `public/assets/audio/beleaguered-castle/` (separate from Golf's sounds).

### 3. Integrate SFX into BeleagueredCastleScene
Following the Golf pattern:
- Add audio preloading in `preload()`
- Create `SoundPlayer` wrapper and `SoundManager` instance in `create()`
- Create `GameEventEmitter` and `PhaserEventBridge`
- Define `EventSoundMapping` binding events to sound keys
- Emit events at all identified action points throughout the scene
- Add `SettingsPanel` and `SettingsButton` to the scene
- Update `createBeleagueredCastleGame.ts` Phaser config with `audio: { disableWebAudio: false }`
- Clean up sound resources on scene shutdown

### 4. Update asset attribution
Update `public/assets/CREDITS.md` with attribution for the new medieval-themed sounds (CC0, procedurally synthesized with Tone.js).

## Risks & Assumptions

### Risks
- **Tone.js synthesis quality:** Procedural synthesis with Tone.js may not produce sounds that feel "medieval" enough without significant tuning. Mitigation: iterate on synthesis parameters; the script can be re-run easily to regenerate sounds.
- **GameEventEmitter expansion:** Adding ~11 new event types to the shared emitter increases the API surface. Mitigation: choose general names (e.g., `card-to-foundation` not `beleaguered-castle-foundation-drop`) that other solitaire games can reuse.
- **Auto-complete sound spam:** The auto-complete cascade can move many cards rapidly. If `auto-complete-card` sounds overlap excessively it may sound unpleasant. Mitigation: use very short sounds; consider limiting concurrent playback or adding a small pitch variation per card for a musical cascade effect.
- **Scene file size:** BeleagueredCastleScene.ts is already 1488 lines. Adding sound integration will increase it further. Mitigation: keep sound setup modular (constants at top, mapping object separate from logic).

### Assumptions
- Tone.js can run in Node.js for offline WAV generation (it supports offline rendering via `Tone.Offline()`).
- The SoundManager, PhaserEventBridge, and SettingsPanel are reusable without modification for a second game.
- The existing `SoundPlayer` interface is sufficient for Beleaguered Castle's needs (no new methods required).
- Players expect sounds on all interactive elements; no subset of actions should be silent.

## Related Work

- **Sound Engine & Golf Game Audio (CG-0MLUDH5JH05H3D9J)** [completed]: Built the SoundManager, GameEventEmitter card-level events, PhaserEventBridge, SettingsPanel, 8 WAV SFX, and Golf integration. This work item extends that infrastructure to a second game.
- **Beleaguered Castle (CG-0MLSDWFLT1WB6IEB)** [completed]: The game this feature targets. All gameplay mechanics (drag-and-drop, click-to-move, auto-complete, undo/redo, win/loss) are fully implemented.
- **SFX generation tool using Tone.js (CG-0MLUJQTSV1CA9APQ)** [open]: Backlog item for a reusable Tone.js SFX generation tool as a separate project. This work item uses Tone.js directly in a one-off script; the reusable tool remains a separate concern.
- **Extend GameEventEmitter with card-level events (CG-0MLUGZPSA0PXNV1N)** [completed]: Added the first 5 card-level events. This work item adds ~11 more solitaire-specific events following the same pattern.

## Suggested Next Step

Create the worklog work item, then break into child items: (1) Extend GameEventEmitter with solitaire events, (2) Generate medieval-themed Tone.js sounds, (3) Integrate SFX into BeleagueredCastleScene, (4) Update asset attribution. Begin with the event emitter extension since it unblocks the integration work.

Fix implemented and merged to main.

**Root cause (Beleaguered Castle):** Overlay buttons were placed inside a Phaser Container. Phaser's sortGameObjects uses camera.renderList for input priority, but Container children are never added to renderList (only the Container itself is). This caused buttons to always sort below card sprites during hit-test sorting, making them unresponsive.

**Root cause (Golf):** Overlay buttons were standalone objects at depth 11, but no interactive input blocker existed to prevent card sprites (depth 0) from intercepting clicks. Without an interactive blocker, Phaser's input system allowed lower-depth card sprites to receive pointer events instead of the overlay buttons.

**Fix (Beleaguered Castle):** Replaced Container-based overlay with scene-level objects tracked in an array. Background rectangle made interactive at depth 2000 to block input. Buttons placed at depth 2001.

**Fix (Golf):** Added a full-screen nearly-invisible interactive rectangle at depth 10 behind the end-screen overlay to block input on objects behind it.
